EDITED BRIEF
BKD - Q4 2017 Brookdale Senior Living Inc Earnings Call
EVENT DATE/TIME: FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 2:00PM GMT
OVERVIEW:
Co. reported 2017 and 4Q17 results.
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
171
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 2:00PM, BKD - Q4 2017 Brookdale Senior Living Inc Earnings Call
CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS
Lee S. Wielansky Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - Independent Director
Lucinda M. Baier Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - CFO
Ross C. Roadman Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - SVP of IR
CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS
Chad Christopher Vanacore Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Incorporated, Research Division - Analyst
Jason Michael Plagman Jefferies LLC, Research Division - Equity Associate
Joanna Sylvia Gajuk BofA Merrill Lynch, Research Division - VP
OVERVIEW
Co. reported 2017 and 4Q17 results.
FINANCIAL DATA
A. 2017-end cash and marketable securities = $515m.
PRESENTATION SUMMARY
I. OPENING REMARKS (R.R.)
A. Management Updates:
1. Board of Directors appointed Cindy Baier as President and CEO and Director effective 02/28/18 to succeed Andy Smith.
a. Announced Lee Wielansky has been elected to serve as Non-Executive Chair.
2. Kathy MacDonald is taking over as SVP of IR.
II. 2017 REVIEW (L.W.)
A. Highlights:
1. Formally ended strategic review.
2. Announced kick-off of strategic review in Feb. 2017.
a. Board and management consisted by legal and financial advisors explore multiple options and alternatives to create and
enhance shareholder value.
i. Throughout this process, mentioned Co. would enter into transaction only under terms that Board concluded would
be in the best interest of BKD and shareholders.
b. Received interest from numerous potential counterparties.
i. Reviewed number of proposals.
ii. Had in-depth discussions with multiple foreign and domestic parties regarding various strategic alternatives, including
but not limited to sale of co.
2
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
172
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 2:00PM, BKD - Q4 2017 Brookdale Senior Living Inc Earnings Call
iii. Went through multiple iterations and negotiations with several counterparties.
iv. Process was complicated by need to incorporate certain third-party consents; conducting parallel negotiations to seek
those consents throughout process.
c. Important outcome of strategic review process was HCP transaction announced in 4Q17.
i. Improved change-of-control provisions in some leased agreements.
ii. Provides Co. with more transactional flexibility.
d. At end of strategic review, Board rejected indication of interest to acquire Co. for $9 per share in cash, which purported
to range up to $11 per share in cash subject to conditions that Board didn't believe were likely to be satisfied.
i. Board didn't believe this offer was acceptable and believes Co. can create more value for shareholders by driving higher
performance of public co. under new leadership.
ii. Board believes rejected offer in current share price of significantly below intrinsic value and below net asset value.
iii. Prior to receiving and rejecting final indication of interest, had other interest and higher prices; pursued each vigorously.
iv. For variety of reasons including necessary consents that would have enabled Co. to transact, none resulted in firm offers.
e. Concluded strategic review.
i. Formal process concluded; as always, committed to evaluating all opportunities to enhance shareholder value and will
continue to do so.
3. Leadership changes:
a. Andy Smith will step down as President, CEO and Board member.
b. Dan Decker has chosen to retire from Board effective 03/01/18.
c. Bill Petty retired from Board.
d. Cindy Baier will become President, CEO and Board member.
III. 2017 BUSINESS REVIEW (C.B.)
A. Highlights:
1. Has underperformed.
2. In past few months by working shoulder-to-shoulder with key operational leaders, analyzed operations to determine what
is working and what is not.
a. Developed concrete plan to focus on key value drivers of business model to improve performance.
b. Will measure progress against pre-established metrics.
c. Will be intentional about what Co. is going on.
d. Has robust roadmap to achieve long-term growth potential.
B. Strategies:
1. Knows real estate philosophy is critical value driver.
a. Goal is to optimize portfolio while opportunistically creating value from owned real estate.
b. After integrating Emeritus communities in 2015, undertook comprehensive review of portfolio.
c. In 2016, began portfolio optimization initiative.
i. Since then, sold or terminated leases for 165 communities; (inaudible) challenged assets in declining markets for
communities in need of significant resources.
ii. Step towards simplifying operations.
iii. Net financial impact to shareholders wasn't significant.
d. During strategic review process, identified assets Co. can monetize, including several high-end communities, by taking
advantage of market where stable assets are in high demand and can command high multiples.
i. May include some highest performing communities where Co. doesn't see same future growth potential as it sees in
other parts of portfolio.
e. Expects to continue pruning disadvantaged assets from portfolio.
i. In 2018, expects to market and sell approx. 30 communities in addition to asset dispositions announced previously;
likely to generate proceeds in excess of $250m, net of associated debt and transaction costs.
3
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
173
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 2:00PM, BKD - Q4 2017 Brookdale Senior Living Inc Earnings Call
ii. In coming qtr., will assess capital allocation strategy for these proceeds.
f. Will continue to look for opportunities to create value from real estate, while Co. pursues turnaround plan to improve
operating performance and financial results.
2. Operations:
a. Operating focus will be based on three [tenants].
i. Attract, engage, develop and retain the best associates.
ii. Earn resident and family trust and endorsements by providing valued high-quality care and personalized service.
iii. Drive attractive long-term returns for shareholders.
b. Plans to return to strong foundation where Co. will differentiate it based on carrying associates who create passionate
[abacus] and generate referrals.
c. Winning locally, while leveraging industry-leading scale and experience.
d. Will make decisions closer to customers by empowering executive directors with more local decision rights.
e. Changing how Co. allocates resources.
i. Improving ability to operate by narrowing focus.
ii. Will start trying to do so much; will eliminate anything that distracts Co. from mission.
iii. Will make sure that associates are able to focus on what matters most, residents.
f. Associates:
i. Will invest appropriately in associates.
ii. On right track with initiatives around key leadership.
iii. Took first step to invest more in top roles in communities.
iv. Made good progress with efforts to improve retention of executive directors and health and wellness directors.
v. Because of this success, expanding program deeper in community organization.
vi. It's more than increasing compensation.
vii. Improving how Co. recruits and on-boards new associates into their roles; has already begun to favorably impact
turnaround by reducing churns in first year.
viii. Will ensure associate interests are closely aligned with work they do that they know that work they do is meaningful
and if they receive proper rewards for their efforts.
ix. Will invest in technology to remove routine tasks, so associates concenter their attention on work they enjoy most,
taking care residents.
x. By building workforce that's valued and supported, can better attract, retain and develop excellent team.
g. Residents:
i. Strategy improved focus on residents and patients.
ii. Unwavering commitment is to customers.
iii. Will continue work on enhancing customer value proposition, differentiating based on quality, choice, personalized
services and associates who care.
iv. Will raise profile on local level with potential customers and their adult children.
v. Will concentrate on customer satisfaction because Co. knows for improving net promoter score, work that delighted
residents correlates with higher performance.
vi. Identified need to change sales and marketing national vs. local mix.
vii. Intends to implement other changes identified to improve performance.
viii. Has initiatives to improve lead management, pursuing the most productive channel, improving initial response and
follow-up on those leads and marketing in local targeted manner.
ix. Discontinuing well-meaning initiatives that distract on things that matter most.
h. Shareholders:
i. Will continue optimize business model to strengthen financial proposition.
ii. Will execute on aforementioned new real estate initiatives.
iii. Over past several years, taken incremental steps with divestitures and G&A cuts.
iv. Committed to taking additional actions to return Co. to great leadership position that's had in past.
4
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
174
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 2:00PM, BKD - Q4 2017 Brookdale Senior Living Inc Earnings Call
v. This week, implementing additional G&A cuts; includes eliminating projects outside of key focus areas, consolidating
operating divisions and flattening organization to get better economies of scale in back-office.
vi. Targeting $25m of G&A savings before normal cost inflation and normalized bonuses; cuts are meaningful to cash flow.
vii. Continuing to assess OpEx to ensure that costs are supporting most important initiatives.
viii. Cutting costs to invest in areas that Co. believes will have lasting positive impact on competitive positioning.
C. Market Conditions:
1. Experienced competitive new openings across many markets.
a. Proactive with actions regarding marketing, pricing and CapEx to meet those pressures.
2. Occupancy seasonally declined in 1H exacerbated by flu season that extended into 2Q.
a. During 2H17, improved occupancy; achieved positive rate growth, those subdued as Co. thought for market share.
3. Labor costs increased due to competition for new associates and intentional investments to improve retention.
4. Portfolio optimization reduced revenue and adjusted EBITDA in short run, while shutting owned and leased assets that Co.
didn't feel strengthened platform in long term.
5. Responded well to significant natural disasters in Florida, Texas and California to protect residents and patients.
a. Events had financial impact on Co.
6. Growth of key metrics impacted by positive reserve adjustments made in 2016 that didn't recur in 2017.
7. Made good progress with balance sheet.
a. Built significant amount of liquidity.
b. Refinanced major 2018 mortgage debt maturities, taking cash on hand to pay off converts in 2018 into account.
i. Has reasonable debt maturities over next five years.
c. As of 2017-end, had $873m of liquidity, including $515m of cash and marketable securities and $358m of availability on
credit line.
D. 4Q17 Performance:
1. No change in macro environment from prior qtr. with elevated competition and material labor cost pressures.
2. Occupancy performance produced 40 BP sequential increase despite difficult Dec., which experienced adverse weather
impact and flu season that was more severe than normal and started earlier than usual.
3. Steady aggregate rate growth even as Co. built occupancy.
4. Proactive with pricing actions.
a. Negative mark-to-market on new move-ins [shrank] from minus 6% to minus 3%.
5. Labor cost increased due to tightness in labor market, wage inflation and Co.-initiated investments.
6. Seeing specific positive impacts of initiatives to improve operating performance.
a. Saw voluntary of Top 3 community leader positions declined 19% YoverY in consolidated portfolio for qtr. and full year.
E. 2018 Guidance:
1. Senior housing business is in mindset of perfect storm of heavy pressure from new supply, wage pressure from tight labor
market, constant pressure of lease escalators and relatively recent pressure of rising interest rates.
2. Expects competitive new openings to remain elevated through 2018 and absorption of new deliveries to create occupancy
pressure throughout year.
3. Has seen difficult start to year with impacts from harsh weather and flu outbreak that began in Dec.
4. Expects based on aforementioned strategy and investments Co. is making that it will begin to demonstrate improvements
as it prepares to return to YoverY growth in 2019.
5. With Cindy Baier's appointment of CEO this week, will take time to continue to study business in thoughtful manner to lead
with REIT and other key partners and further refine near-term plans before issuing formal guidance for 2018.
6. YoverY comparisons will continue to be negatively impacted by impact of announced disposition either due to full-year
effect of 2017 close transactions for those that it closed in 2018.
a. Real estate initiatives will position Co. for creating long-term shareholder value.
7. Pro forma of 2017 results after reflecting impact of transactions that are complete or in process, but doesn't include approx.
30 additional asset sales announced on 02/22/18.
a. Some transactions will be reflected for part of 2018.
5
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
175
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 2:00PM, BKD - Q4 2017 Brookdale Senior Living Inc Earnings Call
8. 2018 will be challenging.
a. With operational changes and investments Co. is making, coupled with focus on execution, should begin process of
improving results and performance and position BKD for future growth and success.
b. Strategy is built on growing topline despite challenges faced in markets.
9. Same-store occupancy slightly down.
a. Portfolio differs from REITs because Co. is starting from lower occupancy base and has more communities in secondary
markets where it projects fewer openings than primary markets.
b. Because occupancy declines are in 2017, has to recapture occupancy loss during 2017 before Co. can grow in 2018.
c. Occupancy to be impacted by flu season.
i. Based on what Co. knows today, this is worst flu season in 20 years as it relates to seniors.
ii. First obligation is to protect seniors Co. serves; closed out communities to new admissions for over 1,000 days in first
45 days of qtr. vs. closing communities for 800 days during entire 1Q17.
d. When communities are closed, can't conduct tours or move new residents in, which has adverse impact on occupancy.
i. Seeing elevated death rate.
10. Same-store total labor costs, including benefits, to continue to grow beyond customary inflationary increases.
a. Expects 5.5-6.0% increase YoverY as Co. invests deeper into organization to improve retention that creates growth.
11. Expects to somewhat reduce per-unit spend on CapEx.
a. Committed to spend appropriately to support business.
12. Needs to fix and invest in operations to get back on right long-term path.
a. Investments will impact YoverY comparisons; they will lead to higher occupancy, stronger rate growth and greater more
sustainable adjusted EBITDA and cash flow.
F. Summary:
1. In late 2017, started to demonstrate progress in key areas.
a. Continuing momentum will allow Co. to overcome near-term headwinds and lay foundation for success.
2. Future demographics will become tremendous tailwind for industry.
a. Healthcare spending continues to increase as population ages and senior housing will play important part in carrying for
this country's seniors.
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Operator
(Operator Instructions) Your first question comes from Brian Tanquilut from Jefferies.
Jason Michael Plagman - Jefferies LLC, Research Division - Equity Associate
This is Jason Plagman on for Brian. So Cindy, just -- I know you touched on this in your prepared comments, but can you just comment
on kind of your key areas of focus for the first -- your first 90 days in the CEO role then even 365 days kind of what are your top 2 or
3 priorities that you'll be spending the most time on?
Lucinda M. Baier - Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - CFO
Thanks for the question. Our top priority is to turnaround our company performance. We're focused on winning locally. This was
very successful for us in the past, and we're confident that our new plans will work. We've already identified and started initiating
changes. We're holding ourselves accountable just like we know you will, not only to make the changes, but also to measure and
report on key operational metrics. We plan to execute on a wide range of initiatives to create long-term sustainable value for our
shareholders.

177
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 2:00PM, BKD - Q4 2017 Brookdale Senior Living Inc Earnings Call
Joanna Sylvia Gajuk - BofA Merrill Lynch, Research Division - VP
All right. And then, you also said that in also the -- one of the slides, talk about reducing or rather realigning how you spend your
CapEx, right? So you have this metric here when you kind of talk about, it seems the recurring CapEx or the community level CapEx.
So can you maybe flush out your view in terms of the different buckets for your total CapEx? Also Program Max and EBITDA, enhancing
CapEx and any piece of corporate versus recurring, how can you -- so how should we think about it for next year or maybe the next
couple of years in terms of changes versus Q4, for example?
Lucinda M. Baier - Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - CFO
So Joanna, we're not giving formal guidance in this call, but what I can say with regard to our community level CapEx, on a same-store
basis, it's not going to be terribly different than 2017. We are expecting to increase our Program Max investments. And as you know,
we think Program Max is something that drives a lot of value for our shareholders. We normally see double-digit returns on those
projects and so we want to invest more there. I will also say that in 2018, we will have hurricane-related Capex as we finished cleaning
up the damage in Florida, primarily from the hurricanes that hit their last year and some extra onetime CapEx potentially to respond
to the new legislation that's in process for Florida generators.
Joanna Sylvia Gajuk - BofA Merrill Lynch, Research Division - VP
Right. So I guess, on that front, so you said it -- you plan to increase the Program Max because that's where you see the highest
returns. So what are the some of the examples of projects that you mentioned that you will try to, I guess, walk away from, so to
speak, or refocus this spending. So is it the cap exposure? Or is it something also that's could on the operating expenses? So any
kind of examples you can give us in terms of things you -- as of now, you decided to kind of reduce exposure because what I'm
getting at is, is there something where you kind of considering maybe reducing your Ancillary Services business at all?
Lucinda M. Baier - Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - CFO
So let me take that question. I think there are a few questions in there. So first with regard to CapEx, we are not reducing the number
of CapEx projects we have by any mean. In fact, with Program Max, we're increasing the number of projects that we have underway,
but as you think about the impact of projects on the community, our objective is to reduce well-meaning initiatives that are impacting
our communities. So if you think about it, there has been numerous, numerous department-driven pilot projects that consume the
time of our community leaders. We have and will continue to eliminate many of these. Regarding streamlining, one example that
we significantly abbreviated was a 600-item questionnaire that previously each community had to complete. We're also improving
our decision rights. And so one of the focus areas that we have is we want our decisions to be as close to the customer as they can
be. So we're empowering our executive directors and that's something that's a pretty big focus for us. With regard to our Ancillary
Services business, we think that's a critical part of our business and we think that it provides a differentiation for our customers as
they're able to get additional care within the same company.
Operator
Your next question comes from Chad Vanacore from Stifel.
Chad Christopher Vanacore - Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Incorporated, Research Division - Analyst
So Cindy, you mentioned occupancy, you're in a difficult December, but also we look at occupancy, it had been up 40 basis points
sequentially in the fourth quarter. So how did that occupancy trend by month?
8
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
178
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 2:00PM, BKD - Q4 2017 Brookdale Senior Living Inc Earnings Call
Lucinda M. Baier - Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - CFO
So we were up in October and November and then we were down in December. Now in December, there are 2 things that were
challenges for us: the first was it was an unseasonably harsh weather pattern and the second was that the flu season started much
earlier this year than it normally does. Normally, we don't see a flu impact until the first quarter, but we did see the flu hit our
communities in Q4, particularly in Northeast. Now as I've mentioned, when there is flu in a community, we basically close the
community. And we do that to protect our residents. We also do that to make sure that we're protecting everyone. So when that
happened, we can't give tours, we can't move new residents in and so because of that you have an impact on occupancy.
Chad Christopher Vanacore - Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Incorporated, Research Division - Analyst
Right. And it seems like that occupancy is bleeding into the fourth quarter, and you had mentioned that the flu had really closed to
-- down for about 1,000 days in that first 45 days in a month. So how has -- how's that occupancy trended in January? Can you put
a number to it?
Lucinda M. Baier - Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - CFO
I won't put a number to it, but what I will say is that in Q1, we normally experienced a seasonal decline. So Q1 is always, almost always
lower than sort of Q4 and 2018 is no different than that. As you did mention, we are having a flu impact. It's the worst flu season for
seniors as it's been in 20 years. And so that has an effect not only on our move-ins, but also in having an increased death rate.
Chad Christopher Vanacore - Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Incorporated, Research Division - Analyst
So to the best of your estimate, what would you say the actual flu impact is over, what would be normal seasonality?
Lucinda M. Baier - Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - CFO
It's too soon to say. As far as we know, the flu impact hasn't peaked yet. It normally peaks about this time, but we're still seeing pretty
elevated path. When we get together on our next call, we'll be able to provide additional clarity on that for you.
Chad Christopher Vanacore - Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Incorporated, Research Division - Analyst
All right. Well, I guess, I will change gears a little bit. And then just thinking about the strategic review process, what were some of
the terms in that indicated offer that you mentioned that the board felt was unachievable or untenable?
Lucinda M. Baier - Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - CFO
Lee, do you want to take that one?
Lee S. Wielansky - Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - Independent Director
As we said in our previous comments, the offer was $9 a share and...

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 2:00PM, BKD - Q4 2017 Brookdale Senior Living Inc Earnings Call

Chad Christopher Vanacore - Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Incorporated, Research Division - Analyst
All right. And then, just one... Go ahead.
Lee S. Wielansky - Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - Independent Director
Just -- I mean, to comment -- I mean, we look at the net asset value of the company, and we felt like that for shareholders that it's --
it's worth a whole lot more than $9 per share.
Chad Christopher Vanacore - Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Incorporated, Research Division - Analyst
All right. Then just switching gears one more time. The G&A cut that you expect to happen in 2018. You are looking at a run rate at
$25 million once fully enacted, when do you expect to get to that full run rate?
Lucinda M. Baier - Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - CFO
So the $25 million is the impact for 2018. An annualized impact of that is over $30 million. And I will say that we've already taken a
large number of the actions this week, in fact. Just to remind our G&A. Now a quick reminder, the $25 million is before normal cost
inflation and before normalized bonuses. Because we underperformed last year, we paid much lower than normal bonuses and our
expectation is that we will perform in 2018 and so we will pay normalized bonuses.
Chad Christopher Vanacore - Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Incorporated, Research Division - Analyst
All right. But to get $25 million, how should that trend through the year?
Lucinda M. Baier - Brookdale Senior Living Inc. - CFO
You should expect to see most of the impact by Q2 and Q3, but you'll see a significant impact in the last part of Q1 as well.

expectations and involve risks and uncertainties. Actual results may differ materially from those stated in any forward-looking statement based on a number of important factors and risks, which are more specifically

EDITED BRIEF
DNR - Q4 2017 Denbury Resources Inc Earnings Call
EVENT DATE/TIME: FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM GMT
OVERVIEW:
Co. reported 4Q17 GAAP net income of $127m and adjusted net income of $48m.
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
182
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, DNR - Q4 2017 Denbury Resources Inc Earnings Call
CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS
Christian S. Kendall Denbury Resources Inc. - CEO, President & Director
John Mayer
Mark C. Allen Denbury Resources Inc. - Executive VP, CFO, Treasurer & Assistant Secretary
CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS
Charles Arthur Meade Johnson Rice & Company, L.L.C., Research Division - Analyst
Richard Merlin Tullis Capital One Securities, Inc., Research Division - Senior Analyst of Oil and Gas Exploration and Production
Timothy A. Rezvan Mizuho Securities USA LLC, Research Division - MD of Americas Research
OVERVIEW
Co. reported 4Q17 GAAP net income of $127m and adjusted net income of $48m.
FINANCIAL DATA
A. 4Q17 GAAP net income = $127m.
B. 4Q17 adjusted net income = $48m.
C. Total debt principal as of 12/31/17 = approx. $2.7b.
PRESENTATION SUMMARY
I. 2017 REVIEW (C.K.)
A. Highlights:
1. Generated significant free cash flow and lowered cost, reaching nine year low on G&A.
2. Co. underspent on capital competitive budget.
3. Grew production for second consecutive qtr.
4. Grew reserves.
5. Had successful well with first significant exploitation investment.
6. Improved balance sheet.
7. 97% of crude oil in production mix, continued strengthening in oil market drove realized price above $55 per BOE.
a. Crude differentials turn positive, up about $2 sequentially.
8. On path to significant improvement in debt metrics with 4Q annualized EBITDA resulting in debt-to-EBITDA ratio of around
4.5 times.
a. Significantly lower than where Co. was earlier last year.
9. Sees path to further improvement over next two years in $60 oil price environment.
B. 2018 Priorities:
1. Co.'s high level parties are the same.
2
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
183
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, DNR - Q4 2017 Denbury Resources Inc Earnings Call
2. Will continue to build foundation of execution.
3. Building on Mission Canyon success, plans to ramp up exploitation activity.
a. Plans to drive incremental value from surplus CO2 and pipeline capacity in Gulf Coast.
4. Yielding development with primary focus on reaching investment decision for initial flood at Cedar Creek Anticline in 1H18.
5. Will continue to drive greater value from existing fields.
6. Will continue to build financial strength.
a. Plans to extend bank credit facility this year.
7. Houston land sales in progress.
a. Expects to begin to see results as early as 2Q.
8. Will continue to maintain capital discipline.
a. Spending within cash flow.
b. Maintaining high bar on project economics.
C. 2018 Compensation Changes:
1. Many of the changes are at executive and full employee base.
2. Key elements include greater focus on project level returns, strengthening of balance sheet and improving debt metrics
and new long-term incentive award focused on debt adjusted reserve growth per share.
3. Co. based its 2018 plan on $55.
a. This allows capital budget of $300-325m, which will keep Co. spending within cash flow.
b. Highlighted activities in this budget are continued development of Bell Creek, developing Phase 6 in the best part of that
field, seven well Tuscaloosa infill project at Delhi, continued EOR development at West Yellow Creek and stepped-up
exploitation program where Co. expects to increase spending to $30-40m.
4. Planning to build out 2017 accomplishments to continue production growth in 2018.
a. 4Q17 was up about 1% sequentially.
b. Expects full-year 2018 to be about 3% above 2017 at midpoint of guidance.
D. Production:
1. QonQ production increased at Delhi, Hastings and Bill Creek.
2. In 2018, expects production to increase in most major fields includes:
a. Bell Creek, where Co. expects a response from recently completed Phase 5.
b. CCA, where Co. will continue Mission Canyon development throughout 2018.
c. Delhi, with Tuscaloosa infill development and Oyster Bayou from just completed recycle facility expansion.
3. Hastings volume should increase with full-year benefit of 2017 redevelopment project.
4. Expects first EOR production from West Yellow Creek early in 2018 and from Grieve around mid-year.
a. Will have benefit of full-year's ownership in Salt Creek.
5. Extreme cold weather in deep south causing power outages and impacted Jan. production.
a. Co. started out 2018 a bit slower than it would have liked.
b. Anticipates that this downtime combined with scheduled maintenance at Delhi and Heidelberg could cause 1Q18
production to be slightly lower than 4Q17 level.
i. This does not affect guidance for 2018.
E. Operating Costs:
1. In line with guidance.
2. Coming in at adjusted $20.53 per barrel for full-year.
3. Benefited from $7m CO2 price adjustment in 4Q17 that reduced actual full-year LOE to $20.35 per barrel.
4. 2018:
a. Expects most LOE categories to remain flat with 2017.
b. Being in different basins for most of the industry and with core business focused on different activities, insulates Co. from
much of the cost inflation it sees across industry.
5. Does see upward cost pressure in two primary categories:
a. Power:
3
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
184
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, DNR - Q4 2017 Denbury Resources Inc Earnings Call
i. Utility, providers and some operating areas have increased their electricity rates.
b. CO2:
i. Higher oil prices will have CO2 price impact.
ii. Sees that as good thing, as it means overall business is that much better.
c. Considering these two elements, expects per barrel LOE to increase by around $0.50 per barrel from 2017.
i. Key takeaway on LOE is that Co.'s improved control and visibility into LOE helps Co. makes conscious, economic choices
that generate the most value for DNR.
F. Exploitation:
1. Will be a greater focus in 2018.
2. Scale of the portfolio is significant at $120m BOE on non-risk basis and $50m BOE on risk basis.
3. Co. is adding to that portfolio every day as teams continue to identify new opportunities across 600,000 net acres leasehold.
4. Mission Canyon:
a. Pleased with first exploitation well.
i. Well executed.
ii. Maintained in tight horizontal target window.
iii. Production results were strong, with initial 30 day avg. rate of 1,050 barrels of oil per day.
iv. It was completed open haul with no stimulation for total drill and complete cost at $3.6m.
b. Running room with this horizon at CCA, and currently think that Co. has around 24 additional locations.
c. Has great drill in first well on two-well pad right now.
d. Has total of six Mission Canyon wells planned for 2018.
5. On Gulf Coast at Tinsley, Co. plans to drill a well in Perry Sand starting around 1Q-end.
a. This well targets [unslept lower primary of] Tinsley with individual well cost between $3-4m and good running room for
additional development.
6. Back up in Powder River Basin, unconventional development of Turner, Parkman, Niobrara, and Mowry has steadily moved
closer to Hartzog Draw Unit, where Co. holds deep rights to around 13,000 net acres.
a. Planning to drill a well here in 2H18 to test prospectivity on acreage, which is held by Hartzog Draw Unit production and
have significant existing infrastructure.
G. Summary:
1. One of Co.'s key focus areas for 2018 is improving financial strength and DNR is taking deep look at how each of assets fits
in portfolio.
2. Last year, Co. disclosed its intent to sell some Houston area acreage and this process is progressing well.
a. Expects to begin to see big results in 2Q18 with parcel sales expected to continue throughout 2018.
3. Has been taking hard look at asset base, and the potential for portfolio management opportunities in 2018.
4. Identified several of Co.'s mature oil fields in Gulf Coast region that DNR plans to market for sale in near future.
II. 4Q17 FINANCIALS (M.A.)
A. Highlights:
1. Adjusted net income $48m.
a. Up from 3Q17's $14m; increase mostly driven by higher revenues.
2. GAAP net income $127m.
a. Primary differences being $78m adjustment for non-cash mark-to-market commodity derivative changes and one-time
deferred tax benefit of $132m, reflecting remeasurement of deferred tax assets and liabilities resulting from reduction of
corporate federal income tax rate from 35-21%.
3. Non-GAAP adjusted cash flow from operations (excluding working capital changes) improved to $134m.
a. Nearly doubling from 3Q, driven primarily by higher revenues.
4. Avg. realized oil price (before hedges) $57 per barrel.
4
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
185
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, DNR - Q4 2017 Denbury Resources Inc Earnings Call
a. 20% increase from realized price in 3Q17.
b. Including impact of hedges, per barrel realized oil price increased 60% sequentially as combined revenues and commodity
derivative settlements increased by $46m.
B. NYMEX Oil Differential:
1. Avg. realized oil prices relative to NYMEX prices.
2. Oil price differential improved by over $2 per barrel from 3Q17, which (inaudible) equates to $11m uplift in revenues.
3. Overall differential of $1.70 above NYMEX prices.
a. Best differential Co. has realized since 2Q13.
b. This improvement was generally related to expanding premium for life of Louisiana suite oil, which averaged over $5 per
barrel above NYMEX prices in 4Q; tracking similarly to increase in Brent prices.
4. Approx. two-thirds of production has LLS index component included in its price formula.
5. Seen CCA and Rockies price differential improved to best level since Co. began operations there in 2010.
6. LLS premium has pulled back significantly from recent highs and is trending in positive $2.00-2.50 range.
a. Co. previously took advantage of the opportunity to lock in LLS to WTI basis swaps at avg. premium above $4 per barrel
to 1H18 to capture a portion of this strong premium.
b. With LLS premium trending down throughout 2018, expects that overall oil differential excluding hedges will also trend
lower.
7. Currently anticipates that overall differential for:
a. 1Q18 will be in positive $0.75-1.00.
b. 2Q18 through 4Q18 to be flat with NYMEX to positive $0.50.
C. Oil Price Hedges:
1. Since 3Q17 conference call, Co. added 2018 hedges covering 10,000 barrels per day of NYMEX and LLS fixed-price swaps.
2. Hedges now represent approx. 65-70% of currently anticipated 2018 production levels.
3. For 2019, Co. has begun to layer in combination of fixed-price swaps in 3-way collars.
a. Initial hedging objectives for 2019 [would project] $55 and provide upside exposure to mid-60s with collars and project
close to $60 with swaps.
4. Plans to continue to add to 2019 hedges over the course of the year depending on market conditions.
D. Expenses:
1. G&A:
a. G&A expense $21m.
i. Down 25% sequentially.
ii. Lowest quarterly level in nine years.
b. G&A per BOE $3.64 per BOE.
i. Lowest level Co. has had in quite some time.
c. Beginning to reflect significant cost reductions implemented in 3Q.
d. Net G&A related to stock-based compensation approx. $3m.
e. Expects 2018 to remain in lower $20m per qtr. with stock-based compensation representing roughly $3-5m of that amount.
2. Net interest expense $23m.
a. Slight increase from 3Q17 due to additional interest treated as debt, resulting from most recent debt exchange transactions.
b. Currently expects capitalized interest to be $7-8m for qtr. throughout 2018.
3. DD&A expense $53m.
a. Slight increase from 3Q17.
b. Expects DD&A expense to be $53-56m throughout 2018.
E. Tax & Others:
1. Income taxes were significantly impacted from Tax Cuts and Jobs Act legislation enacted in Dec., which among other things
lower the federal income tax rate for corporations from 35-21%.
2. Since Co. is in net deferred tax liability position, this reduced Co.'s future tax liabilities resulting in $132m income tax benefit.
5
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
186
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, DNR - Q4 2017 Denbury Resources Inc Earnings Call
3. Expects 2018 effective tax rate will be close to 25% with little or no cash taxes.
4. Build 2018 budget around $55 oil price.
a. Plans to keep spending within cash flow as Co. has historically done.
b. On top, $300-325m of development capital, Co. estimates approx. $30m for capitalized interest, which brings total CapEx
to $330-355m.
5. Estimates 2018 cash flow from operations will be $430-480m, assuming:
a. $55 WTI prices.
b. $30m of interest being capitalized.
6. Due to accounting for debt exchanges completed over last couple of years, roughly $90m of interest on debt will be shown
in financial statements as reduction of debt instead of interest expense.
a. To give accurate reflection of cash available to spend, Co. has subtracted this amount from estimated cash flow from
operations bringing cash flow to adjusted range of $340-390m and giving Co. excess net cash of $10-35m.
7. Excluding hedges, $5 change in oil price would impact cash flow by around $100m.
a. Considering 2018 hedge positions:
i. If prices averaged $50, would expect cash flow reduction of $50.
ii. If prices averaged $60, would expect a gain of $30m in cash flow.
F. Balance Sheet:
1. Pro-forma for debt exchange transaction completed in early Jan.
2. Total debt principal approx. $2.7b as of 12/31/17.
a. $475m outstanding on bank credit facility.
b. Over $500m of remaining borrowing base availability.
3. Since oil price downturn that began in 2014, reduced debt principal by $836m.
a. Earliest maturity of debt as bank facility which matures in Dec. 2019.
i. Started initial conversations with lead bank regarding the extension of this facility in 2018.
b. Main priority will be to retain ample liquidity full access to [$1.050b] borrowing base.
4. Believes that value sustaining asset base and improving debt metrics gives DNR a much different debt profile than what is
reflected in trailing 12-month leverage metrics.
5. Trailing 12-month debt-to-EBITDA ratio is 6.5 times range.
a. Co. sees this improving meaningfully throughout 2018 and 2019, assuming oil prices remain in $55-60 price range.
6. Sees path for Co. to approach 3.5 times total leverage, given $60 oil price environment over next couple of years and with
existing asset base.
7. Based on current projections, expects outstanding bank debt to come down throughout 2018 to $300-400m, largely due
to anticipated proceeds from Houston area land sales.
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Operator
(Operator Instructions) And our first question comes from the line of Tim Rezvan with Mizuho.
Timothy A. Rezvan - Mizuho Securities USA LLC, Research Division - MD of Americas Research
I got a few here. I guess I'll start. The Cedar Creek Anticline EOR decision. Chris, you've repeatedly put out a first half '18 event. And
then the slide deck has language saying that the company's looking to establish a path forward. Given that we're at the end of
February here, the first half is only 4 more months, can you give any color on kind of where you stand or what you're pursuing? Or
how that possibly could look getting to FID there?
6
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us

without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, DNR - Q4 2017 Denbury Resources Inc Earnings Call
Christian S. Kendall - Denbury Resources Inc. - CEO, President & Director
Tim. So the way back I think about these, first of all, it's just such a great target upwards of 300 million barrels of potentially EOR
resource up there, which is well in excess of our total current proved reserve base. So it's something that you really want to chase
after. And what we're doing, even through the downturn, we've kept the permitting process, which is really the main time impact
on the whole project. We've kept that running through the downturn. And I think, what I see us heading towards is a confluence of
getting the permitting resolved to a point where we can proceed, and we're feeling pretty good about that in the first part of this
year. Getting the technical work and getting that piece of done, and that's every bit of that that I've seen as we've come through the
last couple of quarters, is starting to come to a head. Again, with this objective of getting that landed in the first half of this year. And
then, the project work and taking into account some of the learnings that we've picked up over the last few years and reducing --
optimizing the cost of our facilities and making a fit for purpose-type of development on the facility side. That's all coming together,
very focused on getting that decided the first half of this year. And then what I see is that would put us in a position to have the pipe,
which is a major single investment late in 2019, get injection started in '20 and then see first production in '21. So that's the framework
that we're seeing there, Tim. And I think that, at least everything I've seen so far, is very positive.
Timothy A. Rezvan - Mizuho Securities USA LLC, Research Division - MD of Americas Research
Okay. Okay. So are you -- are there plans that you might -- that you may go ahead without really looking for a partner, some kind of
third-party capital infusion on the project?
Christian S. Kendall - Denbury Resources Inc. - CEO, President & Director
No. One piece that I didn't mention in my description there is that we're looking at how we fund that and some different options
there. Honestly, we'd prefer not to take the chunky capital of the pipeline in 1 year. We have a lot of other very nice projects we'd
like to do with that. And so part of the process we're working through the same time is exactly that, is looking at different paths for
bringing in some outside capital for doing that. And as you mentioned, that is a great type of business that, I think, people are
interested in investing in. And so that's something that will happen along the same time and to some degree, perhaps, even beyond
the first half of the year, but I don't see any risk associated with that.
Timothy A. Rezvan - Mizuho Securities USA LLC, Research Division - MD of Americas Research
Okay. I appreciate all the color. And then, perhaps, this is a related topic. You talked about marketing some of your mature assets. It
looks like production a little over 7,000 a day on that. Was that a separate decision from possible funding CCA? Or others kind of --
do you see those as integrated decisions?
Christian S. Kendall - Denbury Resources Inc. - CEO, President & Director
I see them as separate decisions, Tim. That really -- looking at our portfolio is something that we should be doing every quarter, every
year, and making sure that our portfolio makes the most sense for our priorities and where we want to deploy our capital and,
honestly, just our focus. So they are separate, but I do see that at the end of the day, we're -- there's going to be a question of proceeds
from that sale, what are you going to do with those? And we're very open with where that'd be deployed, whether it's into reducing
debt, into the assets and something like CCA or doing something else with it. But that is a possibility, but they were arrived at
separately really just makes sense for us to look at these assets and get our portfolio as optimized as we can.

without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, DNR - Q4 2017 Denbury Resources Inc Earnings Call
Timothy A. Rezvan - Mizuho Securities USA LLC, Research Division - MD of Americas Research

the full year 2017 average, which gets us closer to kind of a 21 level? Or is that from the 4Q '17 kind of level?
Christian S. Kendall - Denbury Resources Inc. - CEO, President & Director

from continued focus at the field level on what we can do to improve that, and we're continuing to work other paths to improving
it. Honestly, optimizing our portfolio will do that to some degree, growing our production will do it to another back. But to frame
that, I think, you're right looking at the full year.
Timothy A. Rezvan - Mizuho Securities USA LLC, Research Division - MD of Americas Research
Okay. Okay. And then, I guess, just one final one. It sounds like the Houston real estate sale it may not be one package but it could
be multiple packages. So is that something that we should maybe just we'll get in like little pieces throughout 2018? Is that how
should we think about that?
Mark C. Allen - Denbury Resources Inc. - Executive VP, CFO, Treasurer & Assistant Secretary
So what -- the way we think about the real estate sale in Houston, Tim, is 2 distinct parts. First, the area in Conroe there that's near
The Woodlands, south of the town of Conroe. And that is one main parcel or one main piece of real estate that's broken up into 7
parcels. And all of those parcels are going out for an RFP on March 1 of this year. So just a couple of weeks from now. And we expect
to have bids in that by the end of March and see some notional -- we expect to get some purchase and sale agreements executed
in the second quarter. So that's something that, I think, you'd see something from us in the second quarter. Then as we move south
to Webster, that this multiple different parcels. Just the nature of their real estate there along the frontage road, on I-45 going down
to Galveston, there are many different nice things we can do with the -- with that property and that will be something that I think
you'll see starting to come in over the course of '18, and might even be beyond that. But there's a lot of interest, a lot of good things
happening there. Kind of 2 different things. A big piece in Conroe that we'll see some numbers on in the second quarter and then
the rest of it in Webster that will happen throughout the year here.
Operator
And we do have a question from the line of Tarek Hamid from JPMorgan.
Unidentified Analyst
This is actually Kevin Quan calling in for Tarek. Just on Mission Canyon, I understand that it's slightly in early stages, but I just wanted
to gauge expectations and sort of any change in geology for your 2 additional wells kind of to the North and South of your initial
pilot well there and any other detail would be helpful.
Christian S. Kendall - Denbury Resources Inc. - CEO, President & Director
So Kevin, what we'd say about Mission Canyon. First of all, it's early days. So we have 1 well that's been producing for really less than
2 months now. Certainly, we're pleased with what we've seen. We want to get more time with the well that we've drilled. We want
8
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, DNR - Q4 2017 Denbury Resources Inc Earnings Call
to get more wells drilled and get some production history behind there. If you look at the map that we've provided for the Mission
Canyon area that we're drilling right now, as I mentioned, we've already spudded the second well on that same structure. And we
really don't see anything different that we expect in the next 2 wells in terms of where we are geologically and what we're looking
for. It's more of just testing the same concept and the same accumulation and establishing some production history. As we move
outside of the Pennel and Coral Creek area, which is one of these first wells will be, then there're some different ideas that we're
going to be testing, but again, all of it is generally the same concept with this fairly narrow interval of Mission Canyon. It's very
productive, and we have some good running room across the CCA area with it.
Unidentified Analyst
Okay. That's quite helpful. And I assume that a lot of the other -- the remaining -- the total 24 locations that you have, that's for the
remaining sort of (inaudible) Creek area and [Little Beaver] and the other regions or are they...
Christian S. Kendall - Denbury Resources Inc. - CEO, President & Director
Exactly. Kevin, if you across the inset map we have there, we have the initial wells in the Pennel, Coral area and then we have those
red ovals highlighting some other opportunities that we see in our leaseholds that are outside of those fields.
Unidentified Analyst
Okay. Got it. And on Slide 17 you kind of -- I'm just hopping back to your capital plan. I just wanted to see the cadence of your capital
projects throughout the year. I know you list quite a few tertiary and non-tertiary ones there. I'm just trying to see how lumpy it
might be towards the end of the year, et cetera?
Christian S. Kendall - Denbury Resources Inc. - CEO, President & Director
I -- just off the top of my head. I don't think that there's any particular jump or drop in capital as we go through the course of the
year. The exploitation piece is working now and will continue. The Bell Creek Phase 6 piece is working now and will continue
throughout the year. So I see it being fairly flat as we move across the year.
Unidentified Analyst
Okay, that's fair. And then, along those same lines, the mature areas -- fields that you mentioned that you're looking at marketing.
Just wanted to get any detail on those particular assets in the sense of what interest look like. I know, again, it's probably early days
as well, but just trying to get a gauge on how soon that might happen.
Christian S. Kendall - Denbury Resources Inc. - CEO, President & Director
So that's something that -- we don't want to share too much of our thinking around that. We can share why we're making this move
but our expectations, and so on, we want to let the process work. But it is something that we expect to kick off fairly soon here, and
we'll see a -- we'll see that out in the public within the next few days actually looking to close it by the end of the second quarter.

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, DNR - Q4 2017 Denbury Resources Inc Earnings Call
Unidentified Analyst
Okay. That's helpful. My last one too, quickly on your revolver. I just wanted to see what your expectations on potential refinancing
might be, given your improvement in reserve base?
Mark C. Allen - Denbury Resources Inc. - Executive VP, CFO, Treasurer & Assistant Secretary
Yes. This is Mark. Yes. As I mentioned, we're starting to work with our lead bank, JPMorgan, and the bank group in terms of extending
that out. We think there's numerous possibilities and, I think, the one thing that really -- and I said before, that differentiates us is
just our assets and they're sustaining value. Yes our leverage metrics have been higher than we would like and we're starting to see
those move here in the right direction. With cost reductions and prices, which is, I think one very positive sign and I think over the
last few years, our bank group has continued to work with us quite well and we just -- we're confident in how we're going to move
forward here.
Operator
And we do have a question from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
Charles Arthur Meade - Johnson Rice & Company, L.L.C., Research Division - Analyst
Sorry for asking again about these Mission Canyon wells, but, I guess, when you make 1,000 barrel a day well for whatever, $3.6
million, people want to know more about it. I'm curious if you can talk about what the, what kind of decline profile you're seeing
and you expect to see in this well? When I just look at your current EOR and the rate, the way those 2 fit together make it seem like
it's a pretty high decline well. But I wanted to just test that because we've gotten to the point -- we've answered the question about
or maybe addressed the question of how repeatable that is, but also how good is this? So can you talk about how -- what you're
seeing in 2 months of decline on this?
Christian S. Kendall - Denbury Resources Inc. - CEO, President & Director
You bet. So what I'd say, Charles, is that first of all, that the EOR that you had seen that we disclosed publically was a predrill expectation
so there's going to be some adjustment to that as we go. I would still say it's early days on how this behaves. But if you think about
just the nature of putting a long lateral in a pretty thin reservoir, we'd expect it to behave, honestly, more like an unconventional
well where you have some fairly high initial decline rates. We're going to keep watching that. We're not to the point where we have
enough of a track record out here with it to really talk in too much detail. But what I would say, look at it to be along the lines of what
you'd expect more in the unconventional side with the benefit of these wells being that we are completing open hole without of
frac and the cost associated with that.
Charles Arthur Meade - Johnson Rice & Company, L.L.C., Research Division - Analyst
That's helpful insight, Chris. Thank you. If I could ask also about -- if you could talk a bit more about the exploitation you're doing at
Tinsley and this Parise Sand. Did I hear you right that is one of the traditional field pays that's maybe under CO2 flood in different
parts of the field? And are you guys planning on going at this with a being frac? Or what's your plan of attack?
10
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
191
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, DNR - Q4 2017 Denbury Resources Inc Earnings Call
Christian S. Kendall - Denbury Resources Inc. - CEO, President & Director
Yes. So what's interesting about that and it's even -- it even applies back to the Mission Canyon, Charles, is that these -- certain of
these reservoirs, when we produce them on primary, when that's complete, they set themselves up very nicely for CO2. And that's
the case with Mission Canyon, and that'll be the same for Perry. With the Perry, it's an area of the Tinsley Field that we don't have
perm for traditional vertical wells to really do a great job of sweeping with EOR so we have a lot of residual oil left in that horizon.
And that's why we're going to attack this one with the horizontals again. We are going to have to put a bit of a frac in these, we think,
to get the rates that we want. So it'll be a little different, although just if you kind of balance the whole nature of the -- of that field
and the depth of the reservoir, our well costs are going to be in the same ballpark as what you saw with Mission Canyon.
Operator
And we do have a question from the line of Richard Tullis with Capital One Securities.
Richard Merlin Tullis - Capital One Securities, Inc., Research Division - Senior Analyst of Oil and Gas Exploration and Production
Just a couple of questions here, Chris. Going back to the potential sale of the mature properties. It sounds like if you're expecting
possibly to have some news in the second quarter, things, I guess, are moving along. Is this more of a package to one party? Or would
you expect to break it up? Have you received inbound interest on this that kind of started things off?
Christian S. Kendall - Denbury Resources Inc. - CEO, President & Director
There is definitely some interest in it, Richard. When we look at how the package is set up, it's actually in 2 separate packages that
are more geographically aligned. We think there's interest, but it's something that I don't see going to 9 different sellers but we
would like to keep it in those 2 packages. But like with all of these processes, you had kind of need to see what the interest is and
how that shapes up.
Richard Merlin Tullis - Capital One Securities, Inc., Research Division - Senior Analyst of Oil and Gas Exploration and Production
Not that you're borrowing much against your borrowing base, but what would the expected impact be to the base and to reserves
if you were to sell the whole package with the associated roughly 7,000 barrels a day?
Mark C. Allen - Denbury Resources Inc. - Executive VP, CFO, Treasurer & Assistant Secretary
Yes, Richard, it's Mark. Yes, we'll need to work through that with the banks. It could be at a level that we'll need to get their permission,
but it's kind of marginal at that point so...
Richard Merlin Tullis - Capital One Securities, Inc., Research Division - Senior Analyst of Oil and Gas Exploration and Production
Okay. Okay. And Mark, I know you also talked about potentially moving the leverage ratio down into the 3.5x level over a period of
years. What levers do you have to pull at this point beyond, say, oil price-related, what's up next?
Mark C. Allen - Denbury Resources Inc. - Executive VP, CFO, Treasurer & Assistant Secretary
Yes. Well, I think we've done a lot of things over the last couple of years. Obviously, we've hit on cost reductions. We've done some
exchanges, utilizing our capital structure and the flexibility that it has provided. I think we still have some flexibility remaining there.

We have some new instruments in the last exchanges in the form of converts, which could provide some optionality, and we'd like

Timothy A. Rezvan - Mizuho Securities USA LLC, Research Division - MD of Americas Research
Okay. It was worth a shot, I guess. And then, a second. You've talked a lot about Bell Creek Phase 5 expansion and Phase 6 coming

see sort of production peak from that field? I mean, how do -- what assumptions do you all have for 2018 baked in, kind of the

Christian S. Kendall - Denbury Resources Inc. - CEO, President & Director

contribution from Phase 5, we still reached a new EOR record in the fourth quarter there, and our teams have just done a superb job
of working through the -- Phases 1 through 4 with -- and optimizing our production there. Did some creative nice work to continue
to grow production from the initial phases. Then Phase 5, we expect to start to see the response. We actually have it completed, as

I mentioned, and we're injecting, and we have the initial response, which is, essentially, water production that's very strong. It looks

identified in the companies' most recent SEC filings. Although the companies may indicate and believe that the assumptions underlying the forward-looking statements are reasonable, any of the assumptions could
prove inaccurate or incorrect and, therefore, there can be no assurance that the results contemplated in the forward-looking statements will be realized.

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 10:00PM, ZIXI - Q4 2017 Zix Corp Earnings Call

P R E S E N T A T I O N
Operator
Good afternoon. Welcome to Zix' Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2017 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Andrew, and I'll be your operator this
afternoon.
Joining us for today's presentation are the company's President and CEO, David Wagner; CFO, David Rockvam; and Vice President of Marketing,
Geoff Bibby. Following their remarks, we will open the call for your questions.
I would like to remind everyone that this call will be recorded and made available for replay via a link in the Investor Relations section of the
company's website.
Now I would like to turn the call over to Geoff Bibby. Sir, please proceed.
Geoffrey R. Bibby - Zix Corporation - VP of Marketing
Thank you, Andrew. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter and full year 2017 earnings conference call. With me
today is our CEO, Dave Wagner; and our CFO, Dave Rockvam. After the market close, we issued a press release announcing our results for the fourth
quarter and full year ended December 31, 2017, a copy of which is available in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.zixcorp.com.
Please note that during the course of this call, we will make forward-looking statements regarding future events and the future financial performance
of the company. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from
those in the forward-looking statements. It's important to note that the company undertakes no obligation to update such statements.
We caution you to consider risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements contained
in today's press release and in this conference call. The Risk Factors section in our most recent Form 10-K filing with the SEC provides examples of
those risks.
During the call, we will present both GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures. Non-GAAP financial measures are not intended to be considered in
isolation from, a substitute for or superior to our GAAP results. We encourage you to consider all measures when analyzing the company's
performance. A reconciliation of certain GAAP to non-GAAP measures is included in today's press release, which can be found, as I said, in the
Investor Relations section of our site.

2
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
