315
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS
Adam Seth Umanoff Edison International - Executive VP & General Counsel
Kevin M. Payne Southern California Edison Company - CEO and Director
Maria C. Rigatti Edison International - Executive VP & CFO
Pedro J. Pizarro Edison International - President, CEO & Director
Ronald Owen Nichols Edison International - President of Southern California Edison
Sam Ramraj Edison International - VP of IR
CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS
Ali Agha SunTrust Robinson Humphrey, Inc., Research Division - MD
Christopher James Turnure JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division - Analyst
Jonathan P. Arnold Deutsche Bank AG, Research Division - MD and Senior Equity Research Analyst
Julien Patrick Dumoulin-Smith BofA Merrill Lynch, Research Division - Director and Head of the US Power, Utilities, & Alternative Energy Equity Research
Praful Mehta Citigroup Inc, Research Division - Director
Shahriar Pourreza Guggenheim Securities, LLC, Research Division - MD and Head of North American Power
Stephen Calder Byrd Morgan Stanley, Research Division - MD and Head of North American Research for the Power and Utilities and Clean Energy
OVERVIEW
Co. reports 2017 core EPS of $4.50 and 4Q17 core EPS of $1.10.
FINANCIAL DATA
A. 2017 core EPS = $4.50.
B. 4Q17 core EPS = $1.10.
PRESENTATION SUMMARY
I. 2017 REVIEW (P.P.)
A. Overview:
1. Delivered excellent 4Q17 and full-year results.
a. Faced significant challenges in Dec. and into Jan. of this year due to wildfires and related legal and regulatory framework
in California.
2. Core EPS $4.50.
a. $0.18 above mid-point of earnings guidance range and well above consensus EPS.
b. Driven by SCE's strong operating performance and additional tax benefits during the year.
2
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
316
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
3. EIX holding co. had better-than-expected cost performance in 4Q and this contributed to positive overall results.
4. Aforementioned results exclude non-core impact of tax reform and revised SONGS settlement.
5. On 02/22/18, Board of Directors declared its 1Q common stock dividend of $0.605 per share.
a. Prior to declaring the dividend, Board evaluated the information available, including information pertaining to wildfires
in Dec. 2017 and mudslides in Montecito in Jan. 2018, and determined that the California law requirements for declaration
were met.
B. Wildfires:
1. Wildfires pose a risk statewide, impacting entire economy.
2. Communities across California have been tragically affected as climate change has increased severity and frequency of
wildfires in recent years.
a. Long-term drought in California and forest management policies have resulted in build-up of unmanaged vegetation.
i. State has nearly 130m dead trees on approx. 9m acres due to prolonged drought conditions and bark beetle infestation.
b. Combination of these conditions, along with decades of more buildings being permitted and constructed in higher fire
risk areas, have contributed to catastrophic wildfires, with eight of the state's 20 most destructive wildfires having occurred
in just last three years.
3. Prevention and mitigation of catastrophic wildfires with sufficient fire suppression resources, and effective policies around
vegetation management, hazardous fuels reduction, and zoning regulations for residential and commercial development
in high fire risk areas.
4. State's infrastructure must be hardened, with stronger building codes in high fire risk areas.
a. Utilities and other operators of critical infrastructure must also partner with state agencies on improved standards for
climate resilient infrastructure.
b. As Co. thinks about how it design and operate system, EIX should consider that roughly a qtr. of service territory is in
designated high-fire risk areas.
c. Should evaluate safety impacts, along with reliability and cost tradeoffs, of steps like:
i. Undergrounding more distribution network in selected areas.
ii. Installing steel or composite poles instead of wood ones in specific locations.
iii. Using further preventive public safety shutoffs of power under high-risk conditions like red flag warnings, which Co.
has done selectively in past.
5. When catastrophic event occurs in spite of all these efforts, Co. needs thoughtful policies around how financial risks are
allocated, including fire suppression costs and damages.
6. California's courts have held investor-owned utilities strictly liable.
a. Regardless of fault, for property damages and attorney's fees if utility equipment is found to be substantial cause of
wildfire.
b. California courts have held utilities liable regardless of fault by applying principle of inverse condemnation; principle
typically applicable to government, not to private entities.
i. Assumption is that, like government entity that can pass along to its taxpayers costs and risks incurred for public good,
IOUs can socialize wildfire costs among their customers in rates.
c. CPUC recently denied San Diego Gas & Electric's application for cost recovery of about $380m of costs above their insurance
coverage.
7. Sees legal, regulatory and legislative policy pathways to resolve aforementioned issues.
a. Recently filed a motion in round fire case, 2015 fire near Bishop, California.
i. Challenging the application of inverse condemnation.
b. On 02/21/18, filed a motion for leave to file an amicus in PG&E Butte fire case also challenging the application of inverse.
i. In regulatory arena, filed joint application with PG&E for rehearing of CPUC's decision in SDG&E's Wildfire Expense
Memorandum Account (WEMA) application.
c. Recently filed comments in PG&E's Butte fire WEMA.
8. Legislative policy changes:
a. Believes that allocation of costs and financial risk must be addressed.
i. That starts with exploring ways to reform the application of inverse condemnation with strict liability to utilities.
3
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
317
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
ii. Includes addressing high cost of fire suppression, which typically exceeds state budget levels each year.
b. Increasingly high premiums for wildfire insurance coverage should be a part of discussion, as they affect parties far beyond
utility sector.
c. Despite Co.'s best efforts and sense of urgency, all of this will take time and creates uncertainty.
9. Believes that the state will ultimately address the risks and issues surrounding wildfires and other climate change impacts
because California's ambitious environmental policies require strong, healthy utilities.
C. Trends For Foreseeable Future:
1. Key trends providing strong growth engine at utility for foreseeable future.
2. Last Oct., SCE released a white paper that outlines Co.'s blueprint for California to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and air
pollution by its ambitious 2030 goal.
a. Clean power and electrification pathway has received great response and support from community organizations,
customers, environmentalists and labor unions.
i. Estimates that, to meet 2030 goals, California must have robust, modern electric grid supplied by 80% carbon-free
energy.
ii. Believes California will need more than 7m electric vehicles, and electrification of one-third of space and water heaters
in increasingly energy-efficient buildings.
iii. Continues to engage in significant outreach to key stakeholders and pursue initiatives to help state meet California's
2030 goals.
b. Related initiative is transportation electrification application that was filed in Jan. 2017 that included $574m of potential
CapEx in two groupings; fast track projects and longer-term projects which will require more detailed consideration.
c. Last month, Commission approved five of the six fast track priority projects Co. proposed totaling $10m in CapEx.
d. Commission process continues with respect to longer term review projects.
i. Still expecting a proposed decision in 2Q.
3. Energy storage is big component of electric grid in Co.'s analysis.
a. Legislation is beginning to reflect this as well.
b. Assembly Bill 2868, signed in 2016, added opportunities for programs and investments of additional 500 megawatts of
distribution-level energy storage systems, distributed equally among the IOUs.
i. SCE's share is 166 megawatts.
4. On 03/01/18 Co. will file Energy Storage Procurement and Investment Plan application, which will include AB 2868 proposals
for Energy Storage Programs and Investments, in addition to the usual procurement of energy storage through other RFOs.
5. With respect to 2018 general rate case, Co. filed updated testimony on 02/16/18 to reflect impacts of tax reform.
a. Has hearing date set for 03/19/18 to discuss this updated testimony and any comments provided by intervenors.
b. Once that hearing is completed, Co. will see if Administrative Law Judges require any other briefings before issuing a
proposed decision.
c. Cannot speculate on timing for a proposed decision and subsequent Commission decision, but given where Co. is today,
would expect the final decision before year-end.
D. SONGS:
1. Announced revised settlement that was due to multiple mediation sessions in 2017 and Jan. 2018 with diversed set of
parties.
a. Weighed reasonable range of potential outcomes and determined that this outcome is in the best interest of customers
and shareholders.
b. If approved by CPUC, this settlement will eliminate further uncertainty and bring will closure to what otherwise could
have turned into lengthy litigation after factoring in likely appeals in absence of settlement.
2. Revised settlement will resolve all issues under consideration in OII.
a. Will result in dismissal of federal lawsuit currently pending in Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, challenging CPUC's authority
to permit rate recovery of San Onofre costs.
3. 2017 financial statements reflect the impacts of revised settlement in Co.
E. Operational & Service:
4
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
318
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
1. While Co. had challenges in 2017 with some goals, saw strong trends in 2H17.
a. Will work hard to meet or exceed 2018 goals approved by Board.
2. Operational and service excellence starts with safety for workers and public.
a. This has been a major priority across Co. and is at the top of core values.
b. 2017 performance did not meet expectations.
i. Rate of injuries leading to days away on restricted duty or transferred (DART) rate, remains worse than industry norms.
c. Continued to improve in customer service goals with residential customers, with SCE ranking in upper second quartile
among peer utilities in most recent JD Power survey.
i. Narrowed the gap with top quartile peers, and first quartile appears achievable for SCE.
ii. On business customer side, peers continued to raise their performance, and Co. has dipped into upper third quartile.
d. While SCE did not meet its 2017 reliability goals, utility began implementing three-year improvement roadmap in 2017,
and benefits realized in 2H17, exceeded expectations.
i. Expects reliability to continue to improve in 2018, with a goal of achieving top-quartile performance over next few years.
3. SCE achieved improved cost performance in 2017.
a. One way Co. measure SCE cost efficiency is controllable O&M per customer.
b. Tracks system avg. rates.
c. SCE continues to reduce O&M costs and maintain lowest system avg. rate among California IOUs.
i. On track to achieve top-quartile performance.
d. Has plans that should help Co. achieve this objective over next couple of years.
4. As Co. continues to pursue top-quartile performance across all operational metrix, EIX knows that the bar will continue to
be raised as Co. and its peer utilities take advantage of technological and analytical advances to improve outcomes.
a. While Co. has plans to achieve top-quartile performance based on current benchmarks, EIX knows that it will need to
work to push past those levels in order to keep pace.
5. As I look ahead to the changes that will take place in California.
a. Utility's [investment will be needed] to operate a safe, reliable grid, achieve environmental policy outcomes, and mitigate
climate change impacts.
b. Customers, regulators, legislators, and shareholders can rely on Co.'s employees to deliver solutions to the many challenges
facing its community, and to do that from strong foundation of operational and service excellence.
II. 4Q17 FINANCIALS (M.R.)
A. Highlights:
1. 4Q17 and full-year 2017 results include certain non-core charges related to recent tax reform legislation and revised SONGS
settlement.
2. Core EPS $1.10.
a. Up $0.13 YoverY.
3. SCE:
a. Had positive $0.14 core variance vs. 4Q16.
i. Mainly attributable to $0.11 per share of increased revenue related to attrition mechanism in SCE's 2015 general rate
case.
ii. There were a number of changes on expense-side as well, although these were largely offsetting.
b. Operations and maintenance costs were slightly higher due to timing of maintenance activities.
c. Net financing costs increased $0.01 per share over last year, mainly due to $0.04 of higher interest expense, partially offset
by increased AFUDC earnings.
d. Income tax benefits were $0.05 per share higher than last year, and related to increased cost of removal benefits.
e. Other costs related to property taxes and corporate expenses were $0.03 higher.
4. EIX Parent and Other had negative $0.01 core EPS variance.
5
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
319
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
a. Arising from lower tax benefits on stock-based compensation at holding co., partially offset by improved results of $0.02
per share at competitive businesses.
5. SCE and EIX results in 4Q17 were impacted by two significant non-core items:
a. Revised SONGS settlement.
b. Tax reform.
6. SCE had $1.48 per share of non-core charges, this relates to:
a. $448m after-tax charge, or $1.38 per share, associated with revised SONGS settlement.
b. $33m charge, or $0.10 per share, related to tax reform.
7. EIX Parent and Other had $1.29 per share of non-core charges, largely related to tax reform.
a. Remeasurement of deferred taxes resulted in $433m expense, or $1.33 per share.
b. Will continue to utilize net operating losses and credits.
8. Based on current analysis, EIX expects to become a cash taxpayer in 2025.
B. 2017 Results:
1. Core EPS increased $0.53 YoverY.
a. Includes $0.44 per share of increased revenue related to attrition mechanism in SCE's 2015 general rate case.
2. Many earnings drivers for full-year 2017 are similar to qtr.
3. At SCE, lower operation and maintenance costs contributed $0.07 per share to overall performance over 2016.
4. EIX Parent and Other realized significant tax benefits in 2017.
a. $0.17 increase in core EPS over 2016 is largely a result of these.
5. For 2017-end, has not recorded liability associated with Dec. wildfires.
a. Given the preliminary stages of investigations and uncertainty as to causes and potential damages associated with fires,
Co. cannot determine that liability is probable or reasonable range of possible losses that could be incurred.
6. Core EPS $4.50.
a. Up $0.18 than midpoint of guidance.
7. SCE EPS up $0.15, due primarily to increased O&M savings and financing benefits and higher income tax benefits.
8. EIX Parent and Other losses of $0.08 per share.
a. $0.03 per share better than guidance, largely from better operating cost performance at holding co. and competitive
businesses.
C. 2018 SCE General Rate Case (GRC):
1. While Co. continues to wait for a decision on SCE's 2018 general rate case, SCE has developed, and is executing against 2018
CapEx plan that will allow SCE to ramp up its CapEx program over three-year GRC period (2018 through 2020).
a. To meet what is ultimately authorized in decision while minimizing associated risk of unauthorized spending.
2. Will focus initial grid mod spending on capital that provides safety and reliability benefits while deferring most spending
that is primarily focused on integration of distributed energy resources.
3. While Co. continues to present 2019 and 2020 capital forecast at current GRC request level, EIX adjusted CPUC CapEx in
2018 to $3.6b to reflect latest planning for the year.
4. Made updates throughout forecast period for changes in FERC projects.
5. Total 2018 CPUC and FERC CapEx plan is $4.2b.
6. While Co. waits for outcome related to 2018 GRC, over long-term, Co. continues to see SCE investing at least $4b per year
and adding at least $2b per year of rate base for foreseeable future as SCE focuses on investments in grid and continues to
be a key enabler of California's ambitious climate change policies.
D. SCE Rate Base Forecast:
1. CPUC rate base forecast is based on weighted avg. rate base that Co. requested in GRC for forward-looking three-year period,
it reflects 2018 through 2020 request level CapEx.
2. Once SCE receives final decision in 2018 GRC, rate base forecast will be updated to reflect authorized levels.
a. At that time, Co. will also update CapEx for 2019 and 2020.
3. Updated rate base forecast to reflect the impact of tax reform, changes in latest FERC capital forecast and additional incentive
CWIP treatment for certain FERC projects.
6
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
320
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
4. Impacted changes since Nov. update:
a. Tax reform has little impact on 2018 rate base, but by 2020, it increases rate base by $400m.
i. Increase is mainly related to elimination of bonus depreciation.
b. During 4Q17, FERC approved incentive CWIP treatment for three additional transmission projects:
i. Alberhill.
ii. Mesa.
iii. Eldorado-Lugo-Mohave.
c. Aforementioned incentive treatment means that Co. can add CapEx related to those projects to rate base in the year they
are spent rather than waiting for project to be placed into service.
d. Thereby, rate base is approx. $500m higher by 2020.
i. This increase is offset by reduced CapEx due to improved cost efficiency and revisions of project scope and schedule
related to FERC capital projects and programs.
e. Cost efficiencies and reduced scope account for approx. one-third of change in CapEx.
i. Remaining two-thirds represents timing shift that will be added to rate base outside forecast window.
E. Current FERC Formula Rate Proceeding:
1. Key matter in that proceeding is the determination of authorized ROE.
2. In Dec. 2017, FERC ruled that requested formula rate would go into effect 01/01/18 subject to refund.
a. While Co. is collecting requested ROE for FERC-related revenues during 2018, these dollars will be adjusted and refunded
depending upon final decision in proceeding.
3. ROE request is comprised of base ROE of 10.3% plus 50 BP CAISO participation adder for total ROE of 10.8% before individual
project incentives.
4. Weighted avg. of individual project incentives increases requested ROE to equivalent of about 11.5% based on current
CapEx plan.
5. In Dec. ruling, FERC also approved 50 BP CAISO participation adder.
a. CPUC has intervened in FERC rate proceeding and has requested an application for rehearing on approval of this adder.
6. FERC also directed the parties to commence settlement discussions and parties are scheduled to reconvene at FERC on
05/15/18.
a. Hearings will be held if parties do not ultimately settle.
7. Cannot speculate on outcome of this proceeding or timeline.
F. Other Details:
1. Will not be providing 2018 earnings guidance until Co. receives final decision on general rate case.
2. Co. lists some key considerations outside of simplified rate base model.
a. Market for wildfire insurance for California IOUs is becoming more strained.
i. Availability is declining while simultaneously premiums are going up.
ii. In late Dec., Co. notified Commission that SCE secured $300m of wildfire insurance for 2018 calendar year and requested
the Commission approve recovery of associated premium of approx. $121m.
iii. Believes Co. has strong case for recovery, until CPUC addresses Co.'s request, one should assume additional $0.29 per
share drag on earnings in 2018.
iv. There may also be additional insurance costs that are in excess of what Co. has requested in GRC.
v. Does not yet have information regarding overall cost however.
b. While Co. is not providing guidance for SCE, does expect EIX Parent and Other EPS drag to be $0.25-0.30 for 2018.
i. Increase is related to lower tax shield due to lower corporate tax rate and higher interest expense.
ii. Includes EPS of Edison Energy, which is expected to improve in 2018 over prior year results as Co. continues to work
towards goal of a run-rate breakeven level of earnings by 2019-end.
c. Has not included any tax benefits related to share based compensation which was a significant factor in 2017 performance.
3. On 02/16/18, filed updated testimony in GRC proceeding to include impacts of tax reform legislation on CPUC-jurisdictional
revenue requirement.
a. Now requesting 2018 revenue requirement of $5.534b.
7
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
i. Down $106m from 2017 revenue requirement.
b. Post-test year revenue requirements have also decreased from prior request.
c. Estimates this latest update will result in approx. 3% CAGR in total rates between 2017 and 2020.
4. Will remain focused on ways to mitigate customer rate impacts while continuing to invest in electric grid infrastructure.
G. Balance Sheet:
1. EIX and SCE continue to maintain a strong balance sheet and significant financial flexibility.
a. At EIX, Co. issued $500m, one-year term loan in Jan. to partially pay down commercial paper program.
b. At SCE, avg. common equity component of total capitalization was 50% as of 12/31/17 including the charge from revised
SONGS settlement.
i. If approved by CPUC, revised settlement allows SCE to exclude $448m after-tax charge from its equity capitalization
ratio.
2. Tax reform results in lower revenue requirement and lower customer rates although rate base will increase due to elimination
of bonus depreciation.
3. Considering aforementioned items and given potential for large capital program based on GRC request and other potential
investments in support of state's clean energy objectives, Co. will likely see increased financing needs in future as higher
CapEx is followed by related growth in authorized rate base and earnings.
a. Will continually assess the most cost-effective approach to financing.
b. Could consider optimizing the use of short and long-term debt at either EIX or SCE.
4. Pleased that Co. is able to benefit from prudently conservative balance sheets EIX has maintained at SCE and holding co.
as Co. continues to invest in SCE.
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Operator
(Operator Instructions) Our first question comes from Julien Dumoulin-Smith, Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
Julien Patrick Dumoulin-Smith - BofA Merrill Lynch, Research Division - Director and Head of the US Power, Utilities, & Alternative
Energy Equity Research
I wanted to first follow up on the change in the parent drag. How are you thinking about mitigating this over time? I know you just
are talking about kind of preliminary '18 guidance here and we're already asking you how you think about it into the future. But
obviously, it's a pretty meaningful move. Can you give us any thoughts on the breakdown of what exactly is in that approximately
quarter of drag and how that evolves?
Maria C. Rigatti - Edison International - Executive VP & CFO
Sure. So I think in the past, we've said a penny and a half per month. I think this looks more like $0.02 per month, plus whatever
Edison Energy is doing. Obviously, over time, the Edison Energy number is one that we are working towards a breakeven run rate
by the end of 2019, so that will be part of the approach to minimize that drag. And at the holding company, tax reform has had an
impact on us. While we believe that from a deductibility perspective, we'll be able to allocate that expense, the fact that we just had
less of a tax shield as a result of the lower tax rate is having an impact.
We always look at operating cost efficiencies from the conversation we just had, or the remarks that we just made that we actually
benefit a little bit in the fourth quarter at the holding company from lower costs. That will be our approach, the same one we've
used at the balance of the company.
8

without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its

322
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
Julien Patrick Dumoulin-Smith - BofA Merrill Lynch, Research Division - Director and Head of the US Power, Utilities, & Alternative
Energy Equity Research
Excellent. And I wanted to follow up on the dividend. Just in terms of the comfort level that the board obviously had in declaring
the latest dividend, how do you think about that evolving as you learn more about the potential exposures here? Maybe said
differently, with respect to the discrete test that you had to evaluate the latest dividend, how do you think about potential risks of
reevaluating that in subsequent quarters here?
Pedro J. Pizarro - Edison International - President, CEO & Director
Julien, I'll take that. This is Pedro. I think like I said in my remarks, our board looked at a broad range of potential negative outcomes
here. I know that we're not putting out a specific estimates that we may have or the like, and I also recognize that a number of analysts
have put out their own sets of ranges out there. But suffice it to say, we took a look at a good broad range of potential outcomes
here based on the information we have at hand and the board felt we're very comfortable making this quarterly dividend decision.
In the normal course, we always update you on dividend actions. We typically have talked about potential adjustments in annual
dividend levels at the end of the year, but then we validate as a board and do actual board approval quarter-by-quarter. And that's
again our normal course, and that remains our normal course. So a quarter from now, we'll be having the next discussion on that
quarterly dividend.
Again, we did look at a broad range of potential outcomes here, so there would have to be some very new information that the
changes that range of outcomes to affect the thinking further. I think that's about the best way that I can frame it at this point, Julian.
Does that help?
Julien Patrick Dumoulin-Smith - BofA Merrill Lynch, Research Division - Director and Head of the US Power, Utilities, & Alternative
Energy Equity Research
Yes, absolutely. So you included the mudslides and the totality of the events that have occurred as best you understand it?
Pedro J. Pizarro - Edison International - President, CEO & Director
I've stayed purposefully vague here, but we did say that we looked at -- we did look at the potential impacts from all these things
that happened. We're not commenting on causation and the like, but the board did take a look at that potential range of impacts
from all these various events.
So I think we've taken a very diligent approach as directors at looking at a lot of ways in which under California regulations and law
that could impact the company and felt very comfortable about the rigor behind the broad look that we took.
Operator
Our next question comes from Stephen Byrd, Morgan Stanley.
9
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its

323
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
Stephen Calder Byrd - Morgan Stanley, Research Division - MD and Head of North American Research for the Power and Utilities
and Clean Energy
I wanted to talk about fire insurance. And I think you talked a bit about this in your prepared remarks. But just generally, as you think
about the cost and availability of fire insurance, I guess, really both for you, but more broadly for your customers and for others in
the region, we hear some concerns about areas becoming uninsurable or costs rising significantly. How do you see that evolving in
California? And I guess relatedly, do you see a political awareness in the legislative body in terms of the need to be thinking about
this holistically?
Pedro J. Pizarro - Edison International - President, CEO & Director
This is Pedro. And I'll start this one and Maria or others may want to comment from the management team.
First of all, you have to date up this insurance forms that we purchased, as Maria described in her comments. I think it's safe to say
that's probably the most expensive premium we've paid for insurance ever. So that alone is a data point on -- there was availability,
but at a much steeper cost than we've seen before. And as we continue to head into the market to secure different elements, different
tranches of our towers, we are continuing to see a very tight market.
But to your point on awareness, that's frankly part of our job right now, to make sure that we are making policymakers aware and
we're fully engaged on that. I mentioned in my remarks that we are engaged with the entire community of policymakers out there,
from the governor's office, through to key legislators. We are doing a lot of that jointly with other utilities or other groups that are I
think aware of the issues here across the state. And again, it's part of not just a utility issue, it's part of a statewide issue here that we
think the severity and the frequency of these fires continues to go the way it's gone over the last 3 years. It's going to continue to
put added pressure on the insurance market and other parts of the economy. So we've taken it on ourselves to make sure that we
are knocking on a whole lot of doors in Sacramento right now, making sure folks are aware and bringing some of our ideas to the
table of what reforms might be needed to solve this statewide issue.
Maria or Adam, anyone from General Counsel, anything you want to add?
Maria C. Rigatti - Edison International - Executive VP & CFO
I'd just say I think it's something that the regulators really need to pay attention to. When we filed our GRC, people were very
appreciative of the $85 million in O&M costs that we had taken out of the system and this sort of insurance premium completely
swamps that. And it does get recovered in our General Rate Cases, we applied for that, so customers will ultimately bear very high
costs unless and until we can make people aware of the issue.
Stephen Calder Byrd - Morgan Stanley, Research Division - MD and Head of North American Research for the Power and Utilities
and Clean Energy
Okay. Just maybe one follow-up on physically as we think about your utility system. Is there a lot of co-location telecom equipment
with your equipment? Or how do you broadly think about the degree to which there is that co-location of there of telecom equipment
with yours?
Pedro J. Pizarro - Edison International - President, CEO & Director
I don't know that we have a fact or figure handy right now, but I'll turn it over to Kevin Payne. Short answer is there is certainly some
level of co-location across the system. Kevin, anything you would add?
10

My dividend question was answered.
Operator
The next question comes from Christopher Turnure, J.P. Morgan.
Christopher James Turnure - JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division - Analyst
I wanted to make sure I had a clear understanding of the role of various agencies in the Thomas fire investigation. Is Cal Fire definitely
the lead agency there? Are there any local fire departments involved? And is there any investigations pertaining directly to the
mudslides that would be separate from that, that you're aware of?
Pedro J. Pizarro - Edison International - President, CEO & Director
Let me pass it over to Adam Umanoff, our General Counsel, Christopher.
Adam Seth Umanoff - Edison International - Executive VP & General Counsel
Christopher, you're correct. Cal Fire is the lead fire investigation agency as they typically are in fires where they're actively involved
in suppression. Separate from Cal Fire, we understand that the Ventura County Fire Department is conducting some level of
investigation.
In addition, the safety and enforcement division of the California Public Utility Commission will be conducting an investigation.
Those are the investigations that we know are ongoing.

without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its

325
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
Christopher James Turnure - JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division - Analyst
Okay. And how we should think about cooperation and timing with the Ventura Fire Department along with Cal Fire for any kind of
ultimate conclusion on cause here?
Adam Seth Umanoff - Edison International - Executive VP & General Counsel
I wish we could give you some comfort on timing. We wish we had more comfort on timing, we don't. These investigations historically
have taken anywhere between 12 and 18 months to complete. And I think we have to stick with that as a suggested time frame, but
there's really no certainty with regard to the time element of these investigations.
Pedro J. Pizarro - Edison International - President, CEO & Director
Adam, these investigations are very much case-by-case based on the facts that investigators pursue.
Christopher James Turnure - JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division - Analyst
Okay. And then in terms of your legal strategy out of the gate here in the court system, is there anything that you can tell us in this
early stage that might make your strategy differ from some of your peers or differ from that engaged by PG&E in the Butte fire last
year? I realize it's obviously still early there and you're probably limited in what you can say, but I'm curious to hear your thoughts.
Adam Seth Umanoff - Edison International - Executive VP & General Counsel
Well, you're correct. It's very, very early. The investigation around cause has just commenced, so I think it really is premature to
speculate as to what the ultimate strategy will be. You will see, as we've seen in other large fires like this, an effort to coordinate
before a single judge, the numerous lawsuits that are brought. And in fact, there is a motion to coordinate the various lawsuits that
have currently been brought in the Thomas fire. That's a procedural step to hopefully make the litigation more efficient, but that's
really at the early stages as well. So not much more we can tell at this point.
Pedro J. Pizarro - Edison International - President, CEO & Director
Adam, maybe I would add and I totally agree with how you framed it and these things are really case-by-case, depending on the
facts in any given case. If you move up, though, to the 10,000-foot level, I think you're seeing indications that from a policy perspective,
not from an individual, legal strategy from an individual case, but from a policy perspective, there's a lot of good discussion and
coordination with our other peer utilities in the state. And you've seen, as I mentioned in my comments, we joined with PG&E in
filing the application for the hearing in the San Diego WEMA case. We filed an amicus in the PG&E Butte case. So I think there's a
recognition that the broader themes around policy and moving beyond just inverse condemnation, that support for a number of
actions across the economy, across fire prevention and hardening infrastructure and costs and risk allocation, those are ones where
at that 10,000-foot level it's so important that we be aligned, and we are.
Operator
Our next question comes from Praful Mehta, Citigroup.
12
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
326
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
Praful Mehta - Citigroup Inc, Research Division - Director
Pedro, you made a point on the call to mention that all this fix around inverse condemnation is going to take some time. Just wanted
to get a little bit more color on that, both from the legislative and legal side. What kind of timing are you thinking about in terms of
solving inverse condemnation right now?
Pedro J. Pizarro - Edison International - President, CEO & Director
Well, again, this is one where, I think, we can give you a sense of that will take time, but it's very hard to pin down, here's the calendar
or here's facing high ends at this very early stage. But let's take it in pieces. There are legal strategies, and so those play themselves
out in individual cases. And I mentioned the Butte case with PG&E or the Round fire case where we made our filing, right? So there's
a track around each of those cases. There's a PUC regulatory track, right? And I don't think that we have a clarity yet in terms of the
timing for the PUC to consider the various applications for rehearing in that San Diego WEMA case or the PG&E WEMA case activity
there. So typical and I'm looking around at Ron Nichols here, but typical CPUC time lines, certainly, it can be in the many months to
a couple of years sort of time frame.
Then finally, to the extent that legislative policy changes attract something that we're also looking at, that happens in cycles of
legislative sessions. And so we have a session that runs through later this year. It's a possibility of next year's session. So we -- I will
tell you we are certainly advocating about the sense of urgency on this, and we would love to see traction in this legislative session
on some of these key pieces, but it's still early days and that's not guaranteed. As I mentioned in my comments, the deadline for bills
has passed, but you can still get changes in those vehicles. So there's always a possibility that as we continue to engage with legislators,
we could see changes in the vehicles that are available already and bills that have been filed.
So that could be a this year thing or it might take longer to help build the momentum and build the case and it could extend into
the next legislative session.
So I'm sorry, I think I took a lot of airtime there to say it's too early to tell. But hopefully, it gives you some color around some of the
other pathways.
Praful Mehta - Citigroup Inc, Research Division - Director
Yes. No, that's super helpful color. So I appreciate that. And just a quick follow-up on the legislative side. Is Senate Bill 819 still the
right starting point? Is that what you're working towards in terms of improving or changing or tweaking? Or is there a completely
different bill? What's the approach on the legislative side, I guess?
Pedro J. Pizarro - Edison International - President, CEO & Director
Ron, do you want to?
Ronald Owen Nichols - Edison International - President of Southern California Edison
There are a number of bills out there. So there really isn't any one specific bill that's been selected at this point that might be modified.
There's vehicles there that can be addressed over time as the session goes on.
13
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
Pedro J. Pizarro - Edison International - President, CEO & Director
And I think it's fair to say that, in general, the bills are addressing very specific issues. You're seeing, for example, a number of bills
around dealing with residential insurance benefits and extending provisions for them and whatnot. What we are advocating for as
you can tell from our comments here is a set of a more comprehensive solutions that deal with this statewide problem across all the
different elements. Now that degree of difficulty then becomes harder because so you're looking for more comprehensive pieces
of action. And that's why I'm saying it's so early days.
Operator
Our next question comes from Jonathan Arnold, Deutsche Bank.
Jonathan P. Arnold - Deutsche Bank AG, Research Division - MD and Senior Equity Research Analyst
Thank you for the comments on this Round fire case on inverse condemnation, I read that earlier in the week. I was curious if you
have any sense of where that is in its process. I know you filed the brief, but are you -- is there a date on which the court is set to hear
it or anything like that?
Pedro J. Pizarro - Edison International - President, CEO & Director
That's a great question for a lawyer. Adam?
Adam Seth Umanoff - Edison International - Executive VP & General Counsel
Jonathan, it's Adam. The motion -- the court has set the hearing date to hear our motion for April 2. And that date can slip. It's always
subject to change.
Jonathan P. Arnold - Deutsche Bank AG, Research Division - MD and Senior Equity Research Analyst
Okay. And is -- then you could see either a ruling or more process after that date, just we're made -- wait to be seen around April 2,
is that the right way to think about that?
Adam Seth Umanoff - Edison International - Executive VP & General Counsel
I think that's right. A lot depends on what the trial court does. If the trial court denies the motion, there's always the opportunity for
us to appeal. These issues may very well require appellate court review, not be settled at the trial court level. And that would take
some significant additional time.
Jonathan P. Arnold - Deutsche Bank AG, Research Division - MD and Senior Equity Research Analyst
Am I correct that in this particular case, the stage it's at, people have just asked for inverse condemnation to be applied to the utility,
but the court has yet to rule on whether that should be allowed?

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
Adam Seth Umanoff - Edison International - Executive VP & General Counsel
Yes, that's a good way -- Jonathan, that's a good way to describe it. In most of these cases, the plaintiffs alleged that the standard of
care that we have to comply with is strict liability arising from the application of inverse condemnation. They simply plead it. And
we have to defend that, or in this case, we challenge it.
Jonathan P. Arnold - Deutsche Bank AG, Research Division - MD and Senior Equity Research Analyst
So in the Butte fire case, the PG&E is trying to overturn a finding. And in your case, you're trying to sort of prevent one, effectively.
Adam Seth Umanoff - Edison International - Executive VP & General Counsel
I can't speak to the procedural status of the Butte case. I don't believe that there's been a final determination. I know they are
challenging the application of inverse condemnation.
Jonathan P. Arnold - Deutsche Bank AG, Research Division - MD and Senior Equity Research Analyst
Yes. So I guess my question was in this case has it also been applied or is it yet to be applied, I just wanted to be sure on that.
Adam Seth Umanoff - Edison International - Executive VP & General Counsel
It has not yet been applied in the Round fire case.
Jonathan P. Arnold - Deutsche Bank AG, Research Division - MD and Senior Equity Research Analyst

terms of tax reform and the like. And we've also had some cash flow impacts from assuming the SONGS settlement is approved, we
have some cash flow impacts there as well. And we are waiting for our rate case to come, and we have a number of other proceedings
where we're also requesting capital. So there's a lot out there, and we're going to stay flexible in terms of how we finance that, either
at EIX or SCE, either with short-term debt or long-term debt. I think that's really all I was really trying to say right now.

330
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, EIX - Q4 2017 Edison International Earnings Call
Pedro J. Pizarro - Edison International - President, CEO & Director
Yes. That's a good question. And I think my answer is
[Audio gap]
I was thinking about pieces, separate tracks, right? So there's a track around the Cal Fire investigation, to the Thomas fire and causation
per se and then what standards will be applied in terms of liability and all of that. There's this broader track around -- the state has
an issue. It's a big issue. Part of the issue is this -- the concern about the application of inverse condemnation feasibility, so the issue
is broader than that, as I mentioned earlier. And so we're really looking for a broader, statewide solution.
Now clearly, there's a connection between these, right? And so if we had a very speedy resolution, and I think that would be wishing
for a lot because we do expect this will take time. But let's say that we have clarity up front in terms of there's a bill that gets passed
next month that resolves the application of inverse, well then it clearly would have some impact on -- once the Cal Fire investigation
concludes, that would have impact on the recourse it means we would have to get recoveries for damages.
But again, I don't think that there's a serial linkage where we have to wait for that Cal Fire investigation of the Thomas fire to conclude
in order to work the various other paths, regulatory, legislative paths to try and resolve the broader statewide issue. I do see this as
fairly decoupled. Does that make sense, Ali?
Ali Agha - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey, Inc., Research Division - MD
It does. To just on that to clarify your opening remarks as well, you talked about the California state goals, et cetera. Are you getting
any conversations back to suggest that there is some recognition coming that, hey, to meet our ambitious climate change and other
goals, this issue is directly linked and impacting that?
Pedro J. Pizarro - Edison International - President, CEO & Director
Without getting into specifics who said what, yes, I think there is that recognition. And a lot of it is driven by the goals and the math
behind the goals. Let's just focus on the 40% greenhouse gas reduction by 2030. That goal alone, the state itself has looked at tools
like electrification of transportation, and building efficiency and renewables, requiring a strong grid, being a part of the solution, a
major part of the solution. I'm glad that we have completed our analysis that lead to our clean energy white paper in the fall because
of that, quite frankly, sharpened our thinking in terms of what it will take for the states to get there. And so that said, with the state,
if the state really wants to get us a 40% reduction and deliver the lowest possible cost for our customers, this is a whole lot of years
from the smart, modern reliable grid that's needed to get 80% carbon-free resources and get 7 million electric vehicles and get a
bunch of water heaters and space heaters that are electric and so on. And so I think folks recognize that, but it is helpful that we
have voices like the Air Resources board who put out their plans. You have the governor upping state's objective to 5 million electric
vehicles. We still stand by our math, which suggests that it's a cheaper path for the state. It's actually more like 7 million electric
vehicles. And I think, Ali, we'll see that continue to surface in various venues. One that I will point to coming up here is the integrated
resource planning process at the CPUC, which will use different scenarios and take a look at our long-term horizon for the resource
mix in California. And that I think will, once again, provide more proof points for the importance of healthy utilities.
Operator
Thank you. That was your last question. I will now turn the call back to Mr. Sam Ramraj.
17
