(Operator Instructions) And we'll take our next question from Brent Thill with Jefferies.
Brent John Thill - Jefferies LLC, Research Division - Equity Analyst
Glenn, just on, yes, some of the comments around the ad campaign. Certainly, many of us still live in the Bay Area have seen the billboards. Just
curious, from a quarter or 2 back, are you finding this to be a more expensive endeavor than maybe originally planned and you -- did you plan on
accelerating these investments on the advertising side or has this been kind of in the books? I know you mentioned this is the largest campaign
that you've run. I'm just curious if you could kind of walk through how you're thinking about the expense structure.
Glenn Kelman - Redfin Corporation - President, CEO & Director
So the expenses don't really deviate from what we planned, at least for 2018, but we do see upside in future years to invest more aggressively in
advertising and drive faster growth than we'd expected. So we just wanted to put everyone on notice that if we see that opportunity to grow faster,
we'll take it. And the reason that we have increasing confidence in advertising is because we have started to see some durable awareness gains
from ads that we ran last year. We have a campaign that we really believe in. The simplicity of the 1% message lends itself well to billboards and
radio ads. And we think it's really going to result directly in more sales. So just having seen some encouraging results, we wanted to maintain our
discipline this year, but also let everyone know that there is the possibility that we will invest more aggressively in the future. So that is the most
likely outcome that we would see an opportunity in future years. It's also possible that we would say, "Actually, this is going so well. We want to
invest more aggressively now." But that's not what we had in mind when we prepared the remarks. So our main thesis was that, in future years,
we could see a larger opportunity to advertise. So we just need to get some early returns and then make a judgment.
Brent John Thill - Jefferies LLC, Research Division - Equity Analyst
Okay. And just to clarify the deceleration in the guidance. I just want to be clear. That is largely related to more the challenging macro conditions
versus any internal execution on the internal team?

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, RDFN.OQ - Q4 2017 Redfin Corp Earnings Call
Glenn Kelman - Redfin Corporation - President, CEO & Director
Well, we ask ourselves every time there's a slowdown or a pickup, "Is it us? Or is it the market?" And sometimes it's us. And sometimes it's the market.
But in this case, we believe that the market has become more challenging, that U.S. sales volume was low in January, as Chris had noted, that
inventory is low. And so we're trying to take measures to grow despite that, and that's why we focus so much on share. When you will see us really
become troubled is if we start seeing market share gains significantly decelerate. It's always going to be somewhat sawtooth, but over quarters,
halves, years, we expect market share to grow fairly steadily. And so that's why we focus on that and not the ups and downs for the market. Chris,
do you want to add anything to that?
Chris Nielsen - Redfin Corporation - CFO and Principal Financial & Accounting Officer
No. I think, Glenn, you said it very well.
Operator
We'll now take our next question from John Campbell with Stephens.
John Robert Campbell - Stephens Inc., Research Division - VP and Research Analyst
Just wanted to take a quick second on the sell-side listing fee. Glenn, it sounds like you guys aren't planning on doing the 1% across the board
anytime soon. But just 2 questions. Do you ever envision a day where that 1% would be across the board in the U.S.? And then I guess, secondly,
as the industry starts to mimic your pricing, do you ever envision maybe even going below that 1% percent mark?
Glenn Kelman - Redfin Corporation - President, CEO & Director
Interesting question. So first of all, we are always focused on lowering our cost of goods sold so that we can expand our addressable market, sell
homes that are very inexpensive and still make a profit or pass the savings on to our customer by offering 1% to more markets. But I don't think
we'll do that in the next 6 months or 12 months. That's a long-term grind to make that pricing work in places where homes sell for $150,000 a year.
We do think that more competitors are going to try to match that price. That is obviously ground on which we like to fight because we've been so
focused on efficiency for so long. So if the market begins to agree that consumers really care about price, I think that's a world where Redfin can
really prosper more than any other brokerage. To go below 1% is possible. I think you have to start thinking about other ways to sell houses that
aren't so labor-intensive. A long time ago, for example, we asked customers to host their own open houses. And back in that day, they did not like
it. They want us to be there, putting the directionals out on the corner and bringing in flowers and everything else. So I think it's possible that there
is a new type of customer out there who wants a new product, but I would think about pricing that's significantly below 1% as inviting a new listing
product. It would be a counterpart on the other end to the concierge product that we developed, which really is serving a customer who wants
just a new level of convenience. And we thought we could take the economic advantage we've developed to actually let us invest more in the
house, more in the service than other brokerage traditionally have. So we would just take that and look at it a different way if we were to try to go
significantly below 1%.
John Robert Campbell - Stephens Inc., Research Division - VP and Research Analyst
Okay. That's helpful. So it just sounds like maybe less touch, less service, less field cost could allow you to do a little bit less than 1%?
Glenn Kelman - Redfin Corporation - President, CEO & Director
I wouldn't do something like that for a little bit less than 1%. We would do that probably if we wanted to offer a new product at a new price. But
it's really speculative right now. It's not as if we have some diabolical plan to do that next week that we just haven't told you about. We just rolled
10
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
422
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, RDFN.OQ - Q4 2017 Redfin Corp Earnings Call
out 1% to almost all of our customers, and it's having a very sharp effect in 2017 and even in 2018. So I think we need to let that play through before
we say, "Here's what we're going to do next."
John Robert Campbell - Stephens Inc., Research Division - VP and Research Analyst
Okay. That's helpful. And then one more if I could squeeze in. On the productivity, I guess, the transaction per lead agent, it just sound like a lot of
that is kind of end market-driven. You guys back to back quarters of declines. You had a long stretch of kind of gains there, but if we just excluded
the market impact, what do you think the -- like peak production per agent can possibly be on total transactions per year?
Glenn Kelman - Redfin Corporation - President, CEO & Director
Well, in what market? In this idealized market, it's a perfectly balanced market with 6 months of supply, I think it's sort of hard to hypothesize on
what agent productivity could be in a market that isn't today's market. We certainly think that agent productivity can increase. That's why we come
to work every day, is to make real estate better and more efficient and to make an agent's job easier so that we can give customers better value.
But we're not sharing our forward-looking projections on where we want to take agent productivity.
Operator
(Operator Instructions) And we'll take our next question from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
Heath P. Terry - Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Research Division - MD
Glenn, curious, we saw a little bit of an increase in revenue per transaction or revenue per home sold in the brokerage part of the business, which
is pretty counter to the trend that we had seen over time. How much of that -- what should we think about as being sort of the underlying drivers
from that -- for that? Is it an increase in the value of the homes being sold? Is it a function of moving up market in certain areas? And then as we
think about the efforts around driving more traffic to the site and sort of brand-building, should we expect that that's largely going to take the
form of television advertising? Or do you see opportunities in online beyond the performance-based advertising that you've been doing thus far?
.
Glenn Kelman - Redfin Corporation - President, CEO & Director
Well, let me take the first question first. I may ask Chris to weigh in with some additional detail. But the pricing or the revenue per transaction is
really a function of mix shift. So we save customers a lot of money when they sell a house through us. We save them a still significant, but less
money, when they buy a house through us. And so we're always calibrating our pricing, especially the refunds that we give to buyers, there's a
commission that's paid to us as the buyer's agent, and then we give a portion of that to the buyer. And we change that amount as the mix shifts
towards listings. So we're trying to keep revenue per transaction steady quarter through quarter through quarter. And if the listing business grows
a little faster than we expected, then we have to lower the commission refund a little faster than we expected. And so what you saw happen now
is just pricing ahead of that. So we know that listings are going to continue to grow very quickly, and we wanted to price ahead of that. And I would
expect that, that will neutralize as listing share catches up to that so that revenue per transaction basically remains constant. And what that means
is that much of our gross margin upside comes from lowering cost per transaction, not trying to increase prices on the consumer. I think it's possible
that we can move up market. Generally, as we do that, we also move down market. We're fairly acquisitive about share. And so if we sell more
expensive houses, it gives us a little bit of latitude to also take on customers who are buying more affordable houses, too. Chris, do you want to
add anything to that?
11
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
423
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, RDFN.OQ - Q4 2017 Redfin Corp Earnings Call
Chris Nielsen - Redfin Corporation - CFO and Principal Financial & Accounting Officer
Just one more comment echoing what you said, which is there is some movement quarter to quarter with regard to revenue per brokerage
transaction, and it has to do mostly with mix. Over longer periods of time, you can see that balance out a little bit. So for all of last year, revenue
per brokerage transaction was actually quite consistent with that from 2016 at just over 30 -- or $9,400.
Glenn Kelman - Redfin Corporation - President, CEO & Director
And then to come to your second question, Heath, just about the shift from traditional media to digital. Everyone sees that coming. More people
are spending more time online. It's just that the major Internet platforms are pricing that into their ads. So we will probably see some of our media
move online, but we're still definitely interested in learning about all the ways we can reach people through traditional media. So we've just begun
with radio and outdoor. And the reason we did that is we just thought we had such a good message for, say, a billboard. Everyone should just know
in a town that you can sell a house for 1% instead of a 2.5% or 3%. And a billboard is the perfect way to get that out. So we wanted to try it.
Heath P. Terry - Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Research Division - MD
Great. That's really helpful. And to the extent the best way to think about your performances is the share gains that you're seeing, any change in
your view or your perception of sort of where those share gains are coming from? Who was losing that share to you?
Glenn Kelman - Redfin Corporation - President, CEO & Director
I don't think there's really been any change. There's certainly some new competitors, but we haven't really seen a change in the dynamics around
market share.
Operator
(Operator Instructions) We'll now take our next question from Jason Deleeuw with Piper Jaffray.
Jason Scott Deleeuw - Piper Jaffray Companies, Research Division - VP & Senior Research Analyst
Yes. So I just want to make sure I understand how the seller mix, which sounds like it's still growing as an overall mix versus the buyer mix, how the
seller mix actually impacts the gross margins of the business. Could you have higher agent productivity because you're more or less guaranteed
a sale representing the seller and you don't have as much of an impact from the homebuyer taking longer to find a house or close on a house? So
I'm just trying to understand the dynamics of the growing seller mix and how that impacts the gross margin.
Glenn Kelman - Redfin Corporation - President, CEO & Director
Well, we make more money from buyers even though it's harder to buy a house than it is to sell one. And that's just because our fees are higher
when we represent a buyer than when we represent a seller. We keep more of the commission in that situation. So what you're seeing as we have
more and more listings as a percentage of our overall sales is that we have to keep more of the commission that is given to us, rather than refunding
such a large portion to the buyer. And that's how we keep revenue per transaction between buyers and sellers basically flat year-to-year. And what
happened last year is we got a little bit behind that because listings grew a little faster than we expected. And now what we're doing is trying to
price just a little bit ahead of that, but the goal is to keep revenue per transaction flat. And trying to answer your question, just remember, we make
more money from buyers than sellers. So as the mix shifts toward sellers, we have to charge buyers just a little bit more to pay for that.
12
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
424
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, RDFN.OQ - Q4 2017 Redfin Corp Earnings Call
Operator
We'll now take our next question from Stephen Sheldon with William Blair.
Stephen Hardy Sheldon - William Blair & Company L.L.C., Research Division - Analyst
Just want to get an update on trends over the last few quarters in the markets where you have 1% commission rate. I get the environment is a little
more challenged lately, but have you seen any notable increase in market share over the last few quarters in those markets? Or is it still too early,
I guess, to see that impact?
Glenn Kelman - Redfin Corporation - President, CEO & Director
I would say that it's early in those markets to declare victory, but it was a well-established finding before we launched in those markets that the
overall impact on share among buyers and sellers accelerates modestly when we shift pricing toward the seller to benefit the seller. And that's, as
we said, because the seller is so much more price-sensitive. She signs a contract before listing her house. She agrees to a price before listing her
house when she chooses an agent. And so in Denver and San Diego and Seattle and places like that, we had run 1% pricing for years. And we
carefully studied whether that hurt our share among buyers, whether it helped our share among sellers. And what we determined was that, overall,
it had a positive effect. And it's possible, of course, that as the market shifts, which inevitably it will, toward buyers, that we want to recalibrate that
pricing to benefit the buyer more. But right now, everybody in real estate wants to represent sellers, and our pricing really favors that.
Operator
We'll now take our next question from Tom Champion with Cowen.
Thomas Steven Champion - Cowen and Company, LLC, Research Division - VP
Apologies if I missed it, but can you talk about your thoughts around gross margin expectations for full year '18? I think there was some commentary
about it on the last call. And then just a quick one. Can you let us know your total markets? I think it's mid to high 80s. But just curious where you
are now and maybe how that should trend going forward.
Chris Nielsen - Redfin Corporation - CFO and Principal Financial & Accounting Officer
Sure. So this is Chris. We haven't set any specific expectations for gross margin in 2018. The commentary on the last call and a little bit on this call
is a point that we're making -- that we are hiring more agents to help even more customers more deeply on the buy side, help them sort through
low inventory situations, low inventory conditions, to find the right home for them. And so -- on a relative basis, that means that gross margin will
hold down because we'll spend some more on agent compensation to help out customers more than we otherwise would. So just directionally,
that's the feedback that we provided. In terms of markets, we are in 86 markets across the U.S. at this point.
Operator
We'll now take our next question from John Egbert with Stifel.
John Peter Egbert - Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Incorporated, Research Division - Associate
I was wondering how longtime Redfin agents are responding to plans to lower the number of customers they'll be working with. Are they worried
this could hurt their individual earnings potential? Or do they buy in to the rationale that this could benefit closing rates across the company? And
13
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
425
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 9:30PM, RDFN.OQ - Q4 2017 Redfin Corp Earnings Call
also, how do you think traditional brokerages are trying to navigate these same headwinds of the housing inventory crunch? Are they employing
different strategies or trying some of the same things?
Glenn Kelman - Redfin Corporation - President, CEO & Director
So the strategy to reduce the number of customers each agent supports was met with widespread enthusiasm at our annual kickoff, which we
held on January 12, even among the most well-tenured agents. And I think it would be different if we were taking them to a level of customers
that was radically lower than what they'd experienced in the past. This is higher than what they had in 2016, just lower than 2017. And I think
everyone just felt that this is exactly the service we want to provide and that we'll actually do better by our customers given the difficulty of the
housing environment. So I would say that I've rolled out, Chris has rolled out, Scott, our president of real estate operations, has rolled out all sorts
of initiatives that have been met with mixed responses at kickoffs. This was one that was universally or near universally embraced. People love it.
Was there a second part to that question? Or was that it?
John Peter Egbert - Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, Incorporated, Research Division - Associate
There was a -- how you think traditional brokerages that you compete with are trying to navigate those same headwinds? Are they employing
similar strategies or different strategies?
Glenn Kelman - Redfin Corporation - President, CEO & Director
You'd have to ask them. I'm not trying to be flip or coy. I just -- I know that when people try to speculate on what Redfin was thinking, I wonder
why don't they just ask us? And in this case I think the most respectful thing to do would be to ask them.
Operator
(Operator Instructions) We'll now take our next question from Brad Erickson with KeyBanc.
Elliot Jacob Arnson - KeyBanc Capital Markets Inc., Research Division - Associate
This is Elliot Arnson on for Brad. Just real quick going back to the deceleration implied for Q1, can you just comment a little bit about the pace of
agent hiring or lead volume growth?
Chris Nielsen - Redfin Corporation - CFO and Principal Financial & Accounting Officer
Sure. So we're not giving specific guidance for Q1 agent hiring, but you can see that both in the third quarter and the fourth quarter, we did continue
to step up our hiring of lead agents. And that's in anticipation of being able to help even more customers more deeply through the first part of this
year and really have those customers in a good position then to get them all the way through the close of transactions in the second and third
quarters. So we're not providing any more detailed guidance on our expectations there.
Operator
(Operator Instructions) It appears there are no further questions at this time. Ms. Elena Perron, I'd like to turn the conference back to you for any
additional or closing remarks.

Expects 2018 revenue to be $1.17-1.19b and non-GAAP net income per diluted share
to be $7.01-7.21. Expects 1Q18 revenue to be $269-272m and non-GAAP net income
per diluted share to be $1.32-1.40.

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, CSGP - Q4 2017 CoStar Group Inc Earnings Call
CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS
Andrew C. Florance CoStar Group, Inc. - Co-Founder, CEO, President & Director
Richard Simonelli CoStar Group, Inc. - VP of IR
Scott T. Wheeler CoStar Group, Inc. - CFO & Principal Accounting Officer
CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS
Brett Richard Huff Stephens Inc., Research Division - MD
David Emerson Ridley-Lane BofA Merrill Lynch, Research Division - VP
Keen Fai Tong Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Research Division - Research Analyst
Oscar D. Turner SunTrust Robinson Humphrey, Inc., Research Division - Associate
Patrick D. Walravens JMP Securities LLC, Research Division - MD, Director of Technology Research and Senior Research Analyst
Peter Corwin Christiansen Citigroup Inc, Research Division - VP and Analyst
Stephen Hardy Sheldon William Blair & Company L.L.C., Research Division - Analyst
Sterling Auty JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division - Senior Analyst
William Arthur Warmington Wells Fargo Securities, LLC, Research Division - MD & Senior Equity Analyst
OVERVIEW
Co. reported 2017 net income of $123m and non-GAAP net income of $154m. Expects 2018 revenue to be $1.17-1.19b and non-GAAP
net income per diluted share to be $7.01-7.21. Expects 1Q18 revenue to be $269-272m and non-GAAP net income per diluted share
to be $1.32-1.40.
FINANCIAL DATA
A. 2017 net income = $123m.
B. 2017 non-GAAP net income = $154m.
C. 2017 revenue growth = 15%.
D. 4Q17 YoverY revenue growth = 16%.
E. 4Q17 GM = 77%.
F. 4Q17 OpEx = $145m.
G. 2017-end cash investment balances = approx. $1.2b.
H. At 2017-end, Co. currently has no outstanding debt.
I. 2018 revenue guidance = $1.17-1.19b.
J. 1Q18 revenue guidance = $269-272m.
2
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
429
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, CSGP - Q4 2017 CoStar Group Inc Earnings Call
K. 2018 non-GAAP net income per diluted share = $7.01-7.21.
L. 1Q18 non-GAAP net income per diluted share = $1.32-1.40.
PRESENTATION SUMMARY
I. 4Q17 REVIEW (A.F.)
A. Highlights:
1. Four years ago, reported $476m revenue run rate, set a goal of reaching $1b in annualized revenue by 4Q18-end.
a. With 4Q17 revenue of $254m, has met $1b in revenue run rate goal an entire year ahead of target.
b. Cross $1b milestone with strongest sales momentum.
2. In 4Q17 generated $43m in net new bookings, sales increase of 47% YoverY.
a. For year, added $127m in revenue and achieved best sales year ever with $148m in net new bookings, up 32% YoverY.
b. Leading this strong momentum, CoStar Suite net new bookings increased 100% in 4Q17 YoverY.
3. Sales of flagship service were off the chart.
a. Added more new companies than ever before with 3,100 net new North American clients added to subscriber base.
i. Nearly triple the number in 4Q16.
b. Added 5,863 new users 4Q17.
4. For all of CoStar, Dec. was best sales month ever by a wide margin and Jan. was second best ever by a wide margin.
a. As a Co., sold more in Dec. 2017 and Jan. 2018, than it did in the entire year of 2011.
5. In 4Q17, apartments.com has its best net new sales bookings qtr. ever.
a. Apartments.com sales were up 36% YoverY in 4Q.
i. Strong performance as historically 4Q for apartments.com and all ILS companies is normally a seasonally weak qtr.
6. For full-year 2017, CoStar revenue growth was 15% YoverY.
a. Four years ago when Co. set $1b revenue run rate goal, also set a goal of reaching a 40% adjusted EBITDA margin for
4Q18.
i. Making good progress towards EBITDA margin goal and remains focused on achieving those strong margins by 4Q18.
7. 2017 net income grew 44% YoverY and EBITDA increased 10% YoverY.
a. Unprecedented sales successes in 4Q17 drove unprecedented commission path for sales force in 4Q.
i. ROI on these sales are fantastic and clear, this continued into 2018 with high commission expenses in Jan.
ii. This suppressed EBITDA growth in 4Q, but in intermediate term, this revenue growth is expected to enhance margins.
8. Co. is in middle of size mix shift in US commercial real estate information analytics and marketing landscape.
a. In the middle of Dec. 2017, major competitor Xceligent suddenly and unexpectedly filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy and
liquidation.
b. Xceligent have been in business since 1999, it was operating in over 40 major US cities.
c. Believes Xceligent had well over 5,000 commercial real estate customers and believes various investors over the years
had poured over $200m into Xceligent.
d. When Co. acquired LoopNet, agreed to divest LoopNet's partial interests in Xceligent as part of an FTC consent decree to
replace any lost competition in merger.
e. At the time of Xceligent's bankruptcy, Co. was engaged in a major lawsuit with them.
i. A former employee of Xceligent has tipped Co. off that Xceligent was stealing and reselling CSGP's data on industrial
scale.
ii. Co. investigated and found out that was true that Xceligent had created thousands of fake passwords and accessed
Co.'s servers millions of times, in fact even 10m times to copy content from it.
iii. Found tens of thousands of copyrights photoshoppped by Co.'s employees that were copied and resold on Xceligent
site.
3
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
430
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, CSGP - Q4 2017 CoStar Group Inc Earnings Call
iv. Had statements from many Xceligent employees that theft was a widespread practice in Xceligent, supported by senior
executives directing their employees and contractors to steal CSGP data and photos and use them to build and sell
Xceligent's products illegally.
v. Believes over the course of two decades, Xceligent never made a profit or even approach breakeven.
vi. Believes by 2017-end, they were spending roughly $5m a month, losing about $5m a month, against approx. $2m or
so of monthly revenue; $2 of loss for $1 of revenue roughly.
vii. Immediately after Xceligent's bankruptcy, recently fired CEO of Xceligent launched a brand new co. called Intrepid that
claimed to have roughly the same data coverage and software that Xceligent had the prior weeks when it closed.
viii. Bankruptcy trustee appointed in Xceligent chapter 7 filing shut the startup down relatively quickly.
f. With Xceligent's failure somewhere around 5,000 companies suddenly found themselves without a commercial state
information system.
i. This left Co. with an unprecedented opportunity to act quickly to pick up tens of millions of dollars of orphaned business.
ii. Co. pulled out all the stops to respond at the maximum level of effort.
g. On short notice in Jan., Co. then launched 30 city road show to market where Xceligent had a presence.
i. With all of senior executives, Co. personally visited 1500 of Xceligent's former clients to let them know all about the
valuable CoStar service it had to offer them.
ii. Went to markets big and small of important from Houston, Atlanta, Miami, Minneapolis, Little Rock, Northwest Arkansas,
Oklahoma City, Kansas City, Columbus.
iii. Objective was to meet as many former Xceligent users as possible, to educate them on the depth and breadth of Co.'s
service offering.
iv. Co.'s service costs more than Xceligent's did and it's well worth it and it's sustainable.
v. All told, about 1,000 CSGP staff were involved in these meetings in person or via videoconference, with hundreds of
flights, believes Jan. 2018 was likely Co.'s highest travel expense month ever.
vi. In order to 1,500 companies into rooms on one week notice, gave away Apple iWatches to highlight Co.'s cool upcoming
CoStar for Apple iWatch product.
vii. Potential net present value of signing up each one of these clients typically can be $50,000 and much, much larger, so
giving them an Apple iWatch to get them into the door for sales pitch, where one has about 30% to potentially 60%
close rate is no-brainer.
viii. The effort has already resulted in Co.'s signing over up to about 1,000 former Xceligent clients, 1000 former Xceligent
client firms.
ix. In addition, this already had a dramatic effect on further improving Co.'s data as these new clients are regularly
contributing updates and sharing information with research team, much more proactively than they have been.
x. Believes this Xceligent development represents a $50m plus annual revenue opportunity for Co.
xi. Many of former Xceligent customers that have yet to sign for CSGP were relying on LoopNet or LoopNet Premium
Searcher as a low-cost alternative to CoStar.
9. LoopNet was another driver behind 4Q sales achievement and successful integration of CSGP and LoopNet databases made
that possible.
a. Prior to 4Q17 loopnet.com and costar.com were each supported by their own separate databases.
b. They were linked and information flowed back and forth between these databases somewhat imperfectly, but by definition,
it could be improved.
c. The separate databases drove higher costs for both CSGP and clients, while degrading data quality.
d. CSGP services are highest-quality professional information tool used by more than 100,000 industry professionals.
e. LoopNet is a marketing platform, with unmatched audience of approx. 5m monthly end users shopping for commercial
real estate each month or a month.
f. Both services are well regarded for their respective brand strengths, there is brand confusion however, significant brand
confusion because LoopNet also has three legacy information products that were frankly inadequate for professionals.
g. They were Premium Searcher, property comps and property facts.
i. Information they presented were notoriously incomplete and inaccurate.
4
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
431
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, CSGP - Q4 2017 CoStar Group Inc Earnings Call
ii. Premium Searcher was largest LoopNet information product and allowed users that paid a monthly fee to see both
advertise listings on LoopNet and ones that brokers had listed for free.
iii. Premium Searcher can see 20-40% more listings on the LoopNet and then a free LoopNet user could see.
h. With the pre-integrated LoopNet in CSGP, half the commercial real estate world updated LoopNet and the other half
update CSGP making neither one the clear and simple go-to solution.
i. That increased research costs under greater quality.
ii. Several years ago, number of LoopNet unlimited listing plans were sold, which allowed brokerage firms to market huge
numbers of listings on LoopNet.
iii. First it was a few dollars a listing, which is just inadequate, these plans were misused and cannibalized both LoopNet
and CSGP revenue.
iv. As part of integration, Co. has been discontinuing these unlimited listing plans in addition to premium searcher itself.
v. There's a little bit of headwind created to Co.'s sales as it winds down those unlimited plans.
i. Notified the client base in early fall 2017 of intentions to discontinue these products.
i. Almost immediately a large volume of LoopNet premium searchers began migrating to CSGP.
ii. As these users begin voluntarily migrating from LoopNet to CSGP, Co. lost the revenue they were paying LoopNet for
information, but typically gained four times that revenue for CSGP subscription.
iii. Just a few weeks ago, notified premium searchers that their service will be can discontinued this month.
iv. There are a small number that will be discontinued throughout year, but overwhelming majority are discontinued as
of this month.
v. As Co. discontinues Premium Searcher in Feb. 2018, expects to lose approx. $1.8m in monthly revenue immediately,
but expect to more than make up the lost revenue within the year as it converts many of these clients to much more
powerful and profitable CSGP Information Solutions.
vi. Expects to see a sales headwind in Feb. 2018, but with offsetting gains through both 2018 and 2019.
vii. This clearly suppresses margin expansion in first two quarters of year, but drives really valuable, potential, intermediate
and long-term EBITDA expansion.
viii. There is never an easy time to intentionally eliminate $22m of annual revenue, but current timing seems the best.
ix. With LoopNet Premium Searcher and Xceligent gone, believes there is more market clarity as clients migrate to CSGP.
10. Through the end of Jan. 2018, converted over 5,400 LoopNet Premium Searchers or heavy searchers to annual CSGP
subscription users at nearly $520 net new per month.
a. Many of these LoopNet users upsold CSGP were paying $0 before, and those paying were paying about $145 per month
on avg.
b. Blended avg. LoopNet price was $49 prior.
c. That successful conversion drove massive surge in CSGP sales in 4Q17.
d. There are approx. 80,000 more discontinued LoopNet Premium Searches or heavy LoopNet searchers who now have
dramatically less access to free content and Co. is focused on upsigning them to CSGP this year.
i. It is Co.'s number one priority.
e. In a market like Phoenix, in the past a broker may have had previously using LoopNet a broker may have had access to
about 75% plus of available listings on Premium Searcher.
i. Now that broker can only see 44% of those listings.
ii. In addition, only CSGP for Phoenix provides details on tens of thousands of tenant sales comps, lease comps marketing
analytics, industry news forecast and lot more.
iii. Believes they will renew at high rate.
f. Commissioned a third party research firm to conduct extensive market research and focus groups during this past Dec.,
Jan., and Feb.
g. One preliminary results one might find interesting is the response, more than a 1000 CRE professional surveyed had to
the following question, a CRE information services you use, which one do you to turn to first.
i. 56% take CSGP, 31% said LoopNet, 3% said Catalyst, 1% said Real Capital Analytics, 1% Pure size, 1% AIR, less than 1%
Reis, less than 1% CompStak, less than 1% Axiometrics, less than 1% Proptylink and 4% said other.
ii. So that is 87% CSGP and 3% for next closest player.
5
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us

without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
432
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, CSGP - Q4 2017 CoStar Group Inc Earnings Call
11. When commercial search was up and running LoopNet captured 23 times more traffic.
a. Now LoopNet captures more than 40 times more traffic than its second closest CRE marketplace competitor.
b. Made significant investments in discontinued significant revenue faster than planned earlier, thereby driving down margins
in 1H of year.
c. Even so, Co. is not moving away from 40% adjusted EBITDA margin goal for 4Q18.
d. One of key factors that made all of aforementioned sales possible was investment in Richmond Global research center.
i. In a little over a year, elevated industry's best database and analytics offering to new heights of excellence.
ii. Now proactively updating 92% of over 1m active listings every 30 days in person over the phone, while vastly improving
tenant data with newly hired 250 tenant researchers.
iii. With addition of CSGP listing manager featured in Oct. 2017, clients and users are adding hundreds and thousands of
updates directly themselves each month in real time.
iv. In first four months, they've averaged over 700,000 updates to listings per month.
e. With an integrated and easier to maintain database, new ability for brokers to update their own listings and greater
industry cooperation, believes and expects that research costs will begin trending back down within the year.
f. Recently were pleasantly surprised by timing in receiving approval from FTC to move ahead and close ForRent acquisition.
i. Closed the acquisition on 02/21/18.
ii. This is the largest acquisition Co. has done to date, measured by revenue and number of employees in acquired firm.
iii. ForRent has 16,000 advertised properties on its network of multifamily sites, in addition to primary site forrent.com they
also offer targeted sites after55.com, corporatehousing.com and forrentuniversity.com.
iv. Similar to apartment finder, plans to run ForRent as a separate website with its own distinct and different website
experience and user interface.
v. With acquisition of forrent.com, multifamily sales was increases by nearly 50%.
vi. Just like Apartment Finder, not planning to do a specific branding campaign or TV campaign.
vii. Plans to focus on online marketing for ForRent.
viii. Advertising and brand work for apartments.com will benefit ForRent, because it gives salespeople, better access to
buyers, because of power of unprecedented apartments.com marketing reach.
ix. Moving as quickly as Co. can to give ForRents customers additional exposure on existing apartments.com network.
x. Believes this will reduce customer churn at forrent.com quickly.
xi. Timing of closing will reduce margin over next two or three quarters, but expects to expand margins significantly in
quarters beyond.
g. Apartments.com continues to grow and strengthen in less than three years Co. has transformed the industry.
i. In 2014, purchased apartments.com.
ii. 2015 acquisition of Apartment Finder and Westside Rentals acquisition in 2017 were awesome and is looking forward
to ForRents contribution beginning today.
12. Multifamily Marketplace revenues grew to $280m in 2017.
a. Up from $86m in 2014.
b. With revenue of $76m 4Q17, finished year with annualized revenue run rate at $304m.
i. Adding ForRents pro forma revenue to that in 2018, multifamily market revenue approaches $400m, and expects to
exit 2018 with over $440m in revenue run rate for multifamily marketplace business.
c. Business is solidly profitable and expects Co. will continue to expand margins as it adds revenue.
d. In 2017, had the most traffic of any apartment listing website.
e. In 4Q17, according to comp score, network attracted over 44m unique monthly visitors in the aggregate for an increase
of 44% YoverY.
i. Co.'s closest competitor RentPath had 21m unique visitors in aggregate which represents 7% decrease YoverY.
ii. In Jan. 2018, with new ForRent enhanced departments.com network, Co. would have almost three times in number of
visits RentPath had.
f. For 27th consecutive month apartments.com was most visited apartment listing network.
i. Had more than 468m visits for year, up 25% YoverY, it's 2.5 times number of visits to RentPath apartment site.

ii. With acquisition of ForRent, it was no longer necessary to renew two year agreement with move.com, expects to be
adding millions of additional unique visitors and visits from ForRent.
iii. Will save millions of dollars here by discontinuing that relationship.
g. Throughout 2017, apartments.com network was ranked Number 1 in traffic in 206 US markets or 98% of all markets tracked
and Number 2 in just a small handful of markets.
i. With initiative ForRent, Co. is now ranked Number 1 in every US market tracked.
ii. Active rentals increased 31% in 2017 and now offers 1.1m apartment availabilities, that have incredible value bringing
consumers and property managers together.
h. In 2017, delivered tens of millions of leads to apartment property managers and owners, resulting in more than 5.1m
leases that were executed because of sites.
i. 5.1m Americans moved into homes they found in apartments.com in 2017.
i. Apartments.com and excellent first year as Co. generated nearly 8m visitors to this site resulting in 15m property views.
i. PR campaign generated 4m impressions.
ii. Apartments.com is the only exclusively Spanish language rental listing site in US with 20% of US rental market speaking
Spanish.
j. Will begin new advertising campaign for apartments.com on 03/12/18 featuring Jeff Goldblum as Brad Bellflower.
i. In 2018, expects to reach 95% of US households with over 5b impressions with another robust national campaign, which
will run from March through Sept.
ii. TV campaign is expected to include [8,000] commercials.
iii. Plans to use a combination of broadcast cable and syndication television, so it will be in top primetime shows, season
premieres, major sports event such as NBA playoffs and college football.
iv. Will be hearing Brad Bellflower on local radio; plans to run estimated 18,000 spots across 10 major markets.
v. Will have strong presence on streaming audio platform such as Pandora and Spotify, expects number of impressions
to exceed 100m.
vi. With addition of ForRent sales teams, now has nearly 350 sales people in multifamily sales force actual producing line
folks.
B. Real Estate Manager:
1. FASB:
a. In 2019, estimates that over 3,500 US issuers will be required to comply and in 2020 another 1,500 private companies will
be required to comply.
b. Co. only has about 5% at this point of total clients and has a lot of room to continue to grow here.
c. Expects sales will remain strong for this group through next couple of years.
2. Turned its best year ever with magnificent 4Q sales and a fantastic Dec.
3. In 2017, net new sales were up 183% over 2016.
4. CoStar real estate manager salesperson Jerry Brink set record for highest subscription sales month ever in CSGP history in
Dec.
5. Another solid qtr. of notable client signings including Nationwide, Citibank, KeyBanc, Ingersoll Rand, Priceline, BNY Mellon,
Ryder Trucks.
6. All of Co.'s analytic reporting is now truly real-time, any time, any of CSGP's 1,850 researchers updates information on
property or when one of its 100,000 some brokers who are putting and listings directly update something that new
information is immediately reflected in forecast, the reports in the data export.
7. Commercial real estate vacancy levels are at cyclical lows and pricing has reached all-time highs.
a. In office sector vacancies have stabilized at 10.3% where they stood in the second half 2017.
i. Pretty healthy level.
8. New construction remains subdued with overall construction numbers running at half of last cycle's peak.
a. For owners of existing buildings, leases rolling over now had typically been signed 3-5 years ago, new lease rates are
higher than those rolling over.
b. Net operating income growth in office sectors is prime for good news in 2018.
7

without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
434
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, CSGP - Q4 2017 CoStar Group Inc Earnings Call
9. Rent growth has slowed over past year as strong growth of 2015 and 2016 have given way to more typical gains about 1.5%
YoverY for office, 2% for multi-family, 2.5% for retail.
a. Industry continues to post extraordinary growth in excess of 5%.
b. RIETs have underperformed broad market over the past year, supply for industrial multifamily and office will put pressure
on tight fundamentals.
10. Home ownership rate has risen for four consecutive quarters, heralding the end of an unprecedented era moving one way
towards apartment demand.
11. Commercial real estate transaction volumes which reached all-time highs in 2016 was lower in 2017.
a. Co.'s analysis of transaction data shows flattening prices.
12. Cap rates appear to have risen marginally in response to interest rate increases.
13. String of good economic news, three quarters of healthy GDP ratings and strong job numbers, and passage of Trump tax
cuts, should provide some fresh tailwinds to real estate fundamentals.
a. Encouraging economic data has also put fed on notice and FOMC raised the policy rate three times last year with future
hikes expected this year.
14. Prospect of higher interest rates could erode an essential value proposition of commercial real estate this cycle, which was
widespread to risk-free rates.
a. For multi-family sector, high-interest rates may support more demand as would be homebuyers are priced at the mortgage
markets and continue to rent.
15. Commercial real estate market is viewed as an effective inflation hedge.
a. Best of all for hospitality sector which reprices daily.
16. When hot markets stabilize, some bad deals can get done, that's why Co. has been building out new analytic offerings and
strong news organization to give customers, brokers, property managers and owners/developers the tools to navigate
these more volatile waters.
17. Taken together, sees a healthy but maturing commercial real estate multifamily sector.
C. Summary:
1. Recent developments like investment to capture share following Xceligent's bankruptcy and opportunity to close highly
potential accretive ForRent acquisition have created margin pressure for 1H18, but Co. believes it will dramatically expand
EBITDA generation in an immediate term and remain on track for 40% adjusted EBITDA margin goals in 2018.
II. 4Q17 FINANCIALS (S.W.)
A. Highlights:
1. Strong momentum exiting 2017 sets Co. up for a strong financial year in 2018 and beyond.
2. Revenue growth:
a. 2017, 15% over 2016.
b. 4Q17 revenue grew 16% YoverY.
c. Organically, revenue growth rate in 2017 came in at 14% for the year and 15% in 4Q after normalizing for three small
acquisitions this year and Thomas Daily acquisition in 2016.
B. Revenue Performance By Services:
1. CoStar Suite:
a. Revenue growth increased to 15% vs. 4Q16.
i. Above top-end of 13-14% guidance range.
ii. Accelerated from strong 13% revenue growth rate in 1H17.
b. Strong revenue growth is in large part due to investment in Richmond and research capabilities and in success in converting
the LoopNet information users to CSGP.
i. Expects CSGP revenue growth rates to improve further in 2018, as Co. accelerates LoopNet conversions and reaches
more of former Xceligent customers that are in need of commercial real estate information.
8
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
435
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, CSGP - Q4 2017 CoStar Group Inc Earnings Call
c. Revenue growth rates for CoStar Suite are expected to be in 18-20% range in 2018; significant increase from approx. 13%
revenue growth rates over past two years.
2. Information services:
a. Revenue growth rate remained negative, as expected, as Co. continues to wind-down LoopNet information products.
b. Decided to accelerate this conversion actively and effectively discontinuing vast majority of LoopNet information service
offerings by end of February 2018.
c. LoopNet information revenue is expected to drop from $32m in 2017 to just $4m in 2018.
i. Almost 90% reduction.
d. Revenue from strong sales in real estate manager business and other information services products lines is expected to
increase from approx. $40m to around $52m; growth rate of almost 30%.
e. Expects total revenue from information services to decline at a rate between 20-25% negative on YoverY basis throughout
2018.
i. Given Co.'s success today in upselling these LoopNet information customers to Co., expects to more than offset all of
this revenue decline with sales of CoStar Suite in coming quarters.
f. Had strong 4Q in multi-family, as revenue increased 26% YoverY and 23% organically.
i. Due to continued strong sales, expects organic revenue growth to continue at over 20% in 2018.
ii. With addition of ForRent, expects multi-family revenue growth of 40-45% for full year.
iii. Consistent with initial estimates, expects revenue contribution from ForRent to be $75-85m on an annual basis, post
integration.
3. Commercial property and land:
a. Revenue grew 19% YoverY.
b. Organic revenue growth adjusting for approx. $2m in revenue from LandWatch acquisition was 12% in 4Q.
c. Strong revenue growth continued in LoopNet tiered advertising products, growing over 60% in 2017 vs. 2016.
d. LoopNet Premium Lister revenue growth moderated somewhat in 4Q17, due to temporary disruptions from CSGP-LoopNet
integration and Co.'s decision to discontinue certain non-subscription advertising products.
e. Expects organic revenue growth in commercial property and land in 12-14% range for 2018, with growth rate at lower-end
of range in 1H, improving towards upper-end of range by year-end as planned improvements are implemented and sales
force efforts accelerated.
C. Key Metrics:
1. GM 77%.
a. Broadly in line with 3Q17.
b. Down 200 BP YoverY, reflecting increased investments in research.
c. Vast majority of cost of revenues related to research operations, which are now broader and more effective than any time
in past.
d. Related improvement in data and product quality is certainly producing strong CoStar Suite sales growth Co. has been
experienced.
2. OpEx $145m.
a. Unfavorable to forecast, primarily due to higher commission expenses related to outstanding 4Q sales performance.
b. In addition to higher commission costs, increased marketing and other sales related costs late in 4Q following Xceligent
bankruptcy in order to reach customers that were suddenly without information solutions.
i. Although unplanned, expects these investments in 4Q and early in 1Q18 to generate significant returns in revenue
growth this year and beyond.
c. Cost associated with Xceligent litigation and bankruptcy activities were $4m, bringing total spend on this matter to approx.
$13m for the year; in line with expectations.
3. Adjusted EBITDA $78m.
a. Approx. $9m below midpoint of guidance range due to higher commissions, [CoStar] marketing and selling expenses.
4. Adjusted EBITDA margin 31%.
5. 2017:
a. EBITDA $237m.
9

without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, CSGP - Q4 2017 CoStar Group Inc Earnings Call
i. Up 10% vs. 2016.
b. Adjusted EBITDA $280m.
i. Increased 9% vs. 2016.
c. Net income $123m.
i. 44% ahead of prior year.
ii. $9m higher than expected.
iii. $9m of additional net income is primarily due to lower income tax expenses, along with reduction in interest expense
related to recent debt restructuring.
6. Number of positive developments impacting tax numbers this year.
a. Recorded $7m tax benefit related to change in accounting rules during 2Q17 for share-based payment transactions.
b. Recently completed a study of research and development costs over past five years.
i. Recognized $8m of research and development tax credits in 4Q.
c. Revalued deferred tax liabilities in 4Q to reflect lower corporate tax rates prescribed in new US tax law that was passed
in Dec. 2017, resulting in $7m benefit.
d. Altogether, aforementioned items reduced effective tax rate to 26% for 2017.
i. Down from rates that were in high-30s previously.
7. 2017 non-GAAP net income $154m.
a. Includes traditional adjustments for stock-based compensation, acquisition-related expenses, and adjustments for write-off
of prior debt issuance assets related to 4Q debt restructuring.
8. Cash investment balances were approx. $1.2b as of Dec. 2017.
a. Currently has no outstanding debt and maintains an undrawn revolving credit line with $750m of capacity.
9. On 02/21/18, used $350m of cash to close ForRent acquisition.
a. Will continue to evaluate investments in strategic acquisitions in line with growth strategy.
D. Performance Metrics:
1. Sales force, which totals approx. 725 sales reps at 2017-end, delivered $43m in net bookings in 4Q17.
a. Increased 47% YoverY.
b. All-time high for Co.
c. $43m of net bookings includes negative $9m in net bookings in LoopNet information services.
d. Start selling LoopNet information products when Co. integrated CSGP and LoopNet databases in Oct.
2. In 1Q18, will discontinue vast majority of LoopNet information products.
a. Expects almost $20m of negative net bookings from LoopNet info products in 1Q, as Co. terminates substantially all of
its agreements with month-to-month LoopNet information subscribers.
b. Over time, expects sales team will continue to sell these customers flagship CoStar Suite products for net positive revenue
results.
i. Expects lower total net new sales in 1Q18 vs. $43m of net bookings delivered in 4Q17.
3. Renewal rates on annual contracts were 91.3%.
a. Up 90 BP from 90.4% in 4Q16 and 30 BP above renewal rate achieved in 3Q17.
b. Sequential increase in renewal rate is most notably due to improvements in multi-family business.
c. Renewal rate for customers who have been subscribers for five years or longer was 97%.
4. Subscription revenue on annual contracts accounts for 80% of revenue.
a. Up from 77% this time last year.
i. Expects this number may temporarily decline, as Co. adds ForRent revenue to metrics in 1Q18, similar to impacts of
prior acquisitions in this space.
E. 2018 Outlook:
1. Revenue $1.17-1.19b.
a. Includes partial year ForRent revenue of $65-75m.
b. Excluding ForRent acquisition, expects revenue for existing organic business to be in range of $1.105-1.120b, which implies
an annual growth rate of 15-16% over 2017.

without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, CSGP - Q4 2017 CoStar Group Inc Earnings Call
c. When Co. completes ForRent integration, expects full-year revenue for ForRent of $75-80m with eventual adjusted EBITDA
margins in range of 45-55%.
d. Currently, ForRent EBITDA margins are around 15%.
e. Believes it will take 12-24 months to fully integrate the business.
f. Expects acquisition to be dilutive to expected 2018 adjusted EBITDA margins by approx. 200 BP.
2. 1Q18 revenue $269-272m.
a. Includes assumption of $7-8m in revenue from ForRent, representing approx. one month of revenue.
3. GM is expected to remain at approx. the same level as 2017 prior to any purchase accounting amortizations from ForRent
acquisition.
a. Amortizations related to acquired intangible assets will impact cost of revenue and these will likely increase.
4. Expects total marketing costs to increase approx. 5% in 2018, prior to ForRent acquisition.
a. First increase in marketing spend level since 2015.
b. Focus of spend will shift towards increasing brand reach in multi-family business.
c. As in prior years, advertising spend is more heavily weighted in 1H with 2Q expected to be largest marketing qtr., as much
as 40% of annual marketing budget expended in 2Q.
5. Expects 2Q being the low point for adjusted EBITDA margins for the year, as was the case in 2017.
6. Expects to invest in growth initiatives, while at the same time growing adjusted EBITDA margin.
a. Investments are focused on taking advantage of these unique growth opportunities in Co. and multi-family businesses.
b. For Co., continues to build product capabilities by expanding field research, improving tenant products, and building on
news content.
i. Will add to commercial real estate sales force to improve reach and market coverage of that team.
c. Expanding research capabilities in London.
i. For multi-family, investing in new software capabilities to benefit renters in Apartments.com and expanding sales
capabilities primarily through inside sales.
ii. Additional investment initiatives are planned and will capitalize on these unique market opportunities.
iii. Expects approx. $25m of spending in 2018 against aforementioned initiatives.
7. Will continue to incur legal fees related to wind-down of Xceligent litigation matters in order to protect stolen data through
bankruptcy process and to conclude open litigations that were ongoing in India and the Philippines against subcontractors.
a. Assumed approx. $4m for ongoing Xceligent related fees in 1Q18, with these costs diminishing in 2Q and beyond.
b. Considering these investment initiatives and before the impact of ForRent, expects adjusted EBITDA margin to increase
by around 350 BP over 2017's adjusted EBITDA margin.
i. This equates to full-year 2018 adjusted EBITDA margins of around 33% at midpoint of range.
8. Adjusted EBITDA margins, including the ForRent acquisition, approx. 31%; at midpoint of guidance range.
9. Adjusted EBITDA $365-375m.
a. Includes approx. $5-7m of adjusted EBITDA associated with ForRent.
b. Regardless of near-term margin dilution associated with ForRent acquisition, remains confident that Co. will achieve goal
of 40% margin exiting 2018.
10. 1Q18 adjusted EBITDA $70-74m.
a. Includes negative impact of approx. $3m from ForRent.
i. ForRent results are negative due to typical purchase accounting adjustments.
b. In addition to dilution from ForRent, as in prior years, 1Q expenses include seasonally higher costs, related to payroll taxes,
annual sales conference and annual standard increases for personnel.
c. Marketing costs increased in 1Q, as Co. increased spending ahead of [apartments] rental season.
11. Discontinuing LoopNet information services in Feb., which has negative impact to revenue and EBITDA.
a. Expects Co. will recoup this, as it continues to upsell these plans to CSGP over coming months.
12. Non-GAAP net income per diluted share $7.01-7.21 based on 36.5m shares.
a. 1Q18 non-GAAP net income per diluted share $1.32-1.40 based on 36.3m shares.
i. These ranges include revised non-GAAP tax rate of 25%, which is well below previous 38% non-GAAP tax rate, primarily
due to tax law changes enacted under Tax Cuts and Jobs Act passed in Dec. 2017.

QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Operator
(Operator Instructions) Your first question comes from the line of George Tong from Goldman Sachs.
Keen Fai Tong - Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Research Division - Research Analyst
I'd like to dig into your margin outlook. You're continuing to target 40% EBITDA margins exiting 2018, but you're elevating your
investment spending in the first several quarters of the year. Out of the categories of investment spending that you've outlined, how
much of that investment do you expect to be temporary in nature, thus giving you confidence that you can actually hit your 40%
target?
Scott T. Wheeler - CoStar Group, Inc. - CFO & Principal Accounting Officer
Yes. George, this is Scott. When you look at what we're investing in, I listed a number of things: expansion of our sales force;
improvements in research; to continue expanding a little bit internationally. All those things are intended to go after these revenue
growth targets that we have and also increase the revenue pace as we go forward. So what we'd rather do now as we go forward,
unlike 2017, where we made significant investments and didn't grow our margins, as we go forward, we want to keep pacing in
these smaller investments as we go and keep raising the margins, like we're doing now, the 350 basis points. So we balance the
investing we need to fuel growth in the future with the margin improvements that we need to make to both hit our commitments
and to give the returns that we committed to. So I don't think I would call any of them temporary. The litigation costs we had in
Xceligent, obviously, were temporary and we'll see those moderate as we go through the year. But the rest of these things are
worthwhile investments for the business.
Andrew C. Florance - CoStar Group, Inc. - Co-Founder, CEO, President & Director
But things like integration of ForRent are temporary or the roadshows are temporary or the unusually high commission costs are
temporary or the $0.5 million of chocolate baskets for Xceligent customers are temporary. iWatches are temporary. There's a lot of
temporary stuff in there that is spent in the first half.
Scott T. Wheeler - CoStar Group, Inc. - CFO & Principal Accounting Officer
And definitely in the first part of the quarter, we had a good, at least, $5 million of those types of spendings.
Andrew C. Florance - CoStar Group, Inc. - Co-Founder, CEO, President & Director
Man, were the kids impressed when I said I bought $0.5 million of chocolate over the weekend. I won't do that ever again.

FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, CSGP - Q4 2017 CoStar Group Inc Earnings Call
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of Peter Christiansen from Citigroup.
Peter Corwin Christiansen - Citigroup Inc, Research Division - VP and Analyst
Super helpful commentary here. I know that you haven't given us margins by segment in the past. And I was just wondering if you
could just at least give us a sense of what the margin trajectory has been like, I guess, the last 12, 18 months in the multifamily side.
And as you scale that, cover your fixed cost, how has that progressed generally?
Andrew C. Florance - CoStar Group, Inc. - Co-Founder, CEO, President & Director
I'll take a rough shot there. We aren't describing -- we're not reporting it at that level. However, I can give you a feel for it. I did a
simple chart the other day of investments being big, red negative bar charts and then 4-wall profit being green. And basically, we
went through -- in '15 and '16, we -- '15, we went through a very significant year of investment as we ramped up the nationwide
brand advertising. Sales kicked up in '16. Those investments basically dropped. Net investment dropped in half, as revenues offset.
And we were -- I was very pleased in '17 to see clear-cut strong 4-wall profitability in Apartments.com. And then after we get through
all the noise and friction of closing a major acquisition, and even without it, then you move into even stronger margin growth. So I
think the margins we're seeing now, the contribution we're seeing from Apartments.com is very successful and, certainly, dramatically
more margin than we ever saw from the individual acquired company. So really good results, we think, people that we're very happy
with.
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of Brett Huff from Stephens, Inc.
Brett Richard Huff - Stephens Inc., Research Division - MD
In the -- I want you to reiterate what you said on something, the incremental amounts that you guys are making on the incremental
LoopNet user. I think you said the blended rate between the non-payers and the payers was something like $50 a user per month,
and you're making net $500. So just reiterate -- I want to make sure I got that right. And then how does that -- is that the data that
we've gotten so far on the 5,400? And do we expect that same kind of pricing lift to continue? Or will it taper? I mean, are we getting
the most juicy leads now and it should get less juicy over time in terms of pricing? Can you kind of go through that?
Andrew C. Florance - CoStar Group, Inc. - Co-Founder, CEO, President & Director
Sure. Yes, so you're right. It's again just like the last time, we really pushed this a couple of years ago. The majority of the folks choosing
to subscribe go from heavy searching in LoopNet to subscribing to CoStar to get better information product. There are folks paying
absolutely nothing to LoopNet currently. So most of them are paying nothing. Those who are paying are paying $149. The blended
rate is $49. We're picking them up at about $520, $540 net, as they go into CoStar. So fantastic, 10x sort of uplift. To answer your
question, are we getting the low-hanging fruit first, absolutely not. I've sat there, I've been in 20 or 30 cities in the last month and
sat in a lot of focus groups watching people talk. And this, it's pretty straightforward to us. But as people sort out the differences
between the different products and LoopNet as a marketing platform, CoStar as an information platform, it takes a little bit of time.
Still, the #1 competition to CoStar is these folks using the -- being heavy searchers in LoopNet or formerly using Premium Searcher.
With the changes in the integrated back-end, when these people go into LoopNet product today, they're now seeing all the CoStar
icons showing listings that they can't see using their LoopNet account, and it's very compelling. And it will take a little bit of time.
The people aren't going to immediately commit to a 1-year, 2-year, 3-year CoStar contract. They've got to actually sort out. Sales
13
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
440
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, CSGP - Q4 2017 CoStar Group Inc Earnings Call
people got to -- have to meet with them. Honestly, we have a bigger opportunity than we have number of salespeople. We mitigate
that. We're shifting our resource around. But it's something that takes time. And there isn't something -- there's still very significant
system flow of folks who, we think, will continuously come in and upgrade to CoStar. February will be -- we are eliminating some of
the standard pricing we had in December, January. We're being more rigorous in our pricing controls. But big picture, we anticipate
it will flow throughout the year and into '19, and it's a very compelling proposition -- value proposition to folks. But it just isn't
something where to turn a switch and people will jump over. It takes time.
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of David Ridley-Lane from Bank of America.
David Emerson Ridley-Lane - BofA Merrill Lynch, Research Division - VP
So LoopNet had roughly 1,700 paying customers. You had another 80,000 pretty intensive users. Given the conversions to date, you
converted just 5% of the base. I'm curious what drove the decision to accelerate the conversion, particularly because you had the
Xceligent bankruptcy, which is obviously a large opportunity that you need to capitalize on as well.
Andrew C. Florance - CoStar Group, Inc. - Co-Founder, CEO, President & Director
Okay. So I think the number of subscribers is close to 32,000 because you have to look at folks who were getting Premium Lister with
a subscriber element or unlimited listers. So the numbers is not -- I think it's higher than 17,000. It's closer to 30 -- 32,000. And then
you had another 50,000, 60,000 that we classify as heavy searchers on LoopNet. The reason you would accelerate -- like, so you're --
originally, we had contemplated rolling out that Premium Searcher over a 12-, 18-month time frame just to continue the rolling time
period. When you look at the folks who are using Xceligent as an information system, a very, very large number were supplementing
the inadequacies of Xceligent's system by using LoopNet, so it's actually one and the same thing. And the changes that occurred at
Xceligent, you're working against yourself when you are providing a Premium Searcher product to someone that you're trying to
convert into CoStar. So you're probably -- you're providing a low-cost, low-value product to them to prevent them from making a
decision to go over to CoStar. And you plan to eliminate it anyhow and you communicate it to them prior to the Xceligent bankruptcy
that you're going to eliminate it anyhow. And also, I think we have to work to a slightly higher standard now on how we treat all our
customers given our increased competitive position. So we didn't want to be in any situation where we were picking and choosing
which markets or which people we eliminate Premium Searcher on and have any image that we were handpicking discontinued
Xceligent clients to discontinue their Premium Searcher. So we went ahead and just did across-the-board and including, in some
cases, making the right choice, the difficult choice to eliminate Premium Searcher with a person who was also subscribing to CoStar
currently, so it's just good customer service. But they're related. They're directly related. It's one and the same decision-making
process. And by doing this, we facilitate a faster, good result across the overall, though you take a -- it requires a little bit of extra
character in the first half of the year. By the way, I listened to -- we have a pretty sophisticated phone system, monitoring system. It
can listen to sales pitches and you just listen to -- I listen to 100 salespeople trying to sell various products to former Xceligent folks.
And you can see the person saying, "Well, I'm trying to figure out what I'm going to do," while you're watching them do 100 searches
that we can LoopNet Premium Search it, like we're just working against ourselves here. So that's really why they're related.
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of Sterling Auty from JP Morgan.
14
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
�2018 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited
without the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its
affiliated companies.
441
FEBRUARY 22, 2018 / 4:00PM, CSGP - Q4 2017 CoStar Group Inc Earnings Call
Sterling Auty - JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division - Senior Analyst
So I want to go deeper into the conversions and the price. So you're netting out, call it, $500 on these conversions. Given that huge
untapped base that you still have yet to convert, based on the focus groups that you've done, what do you think is realistic in terms
of how -- what percentage that you can bring over and at what price point? Because I think, at the beginning of the process, you've
talked about maybe doing a $200 level of functionality, maybe a $400 level of functionality and then we'll call it CoStar. Had that
kind of pricing approach or strategy morphed as you've done more work in the space?
Andrew C. Florance - CoStar Group, Inc. - Co-Founder, CEO, President & Director
Yes, it changed a little bit. So it's a -- we initially were focusing on, as you said, the $200, $400. We're not getting a lot of pickup in
the $200. People are -- if they know what they're -- if they don't know what they're doing, some of them accidentally buy the $200.
But this is what they do for a living. This is their trade. This is their Bloomberg terminal. And the $400 solution is incredibly powerful
and gives them an amazing information solution with tons of revenue-generating opportunities. The $200 is adequate and meets
everything that LoopNet Premium Searcher was doing and a lot more. So I think it's probably 19 of the $400 to 1 of the $200. And
that's just what people are opting for. And I think it's actually shifting even further. So I think it will be like sub-5%, sub-3% of the
lower cost solution at the customers' behest. So -- and again, in the focus groups, it's just amazing how they're all just trying to figure
out what's going on. You've got Xceligent. You've got these board systems. You've got LoopNet Premium Searcher, Premium Lister.
You've got CoStar. And you would think it was pretty easy for them to sort it out. There's a lot of confusion out there. And what we're
doing is we're really simplifying that decision-making process for them. And it will take 1 year or so to sort of really simplify this and
get them migrated into the right products. But we're highly confident that a very substantial portion of these folks will ultimately
be using CoStar for information and LoopNet for marketing. One of the things I don't think we spent a lot of time on the call that
did come out loud and clear in these most recent rounds of focus groups is one of the beautiful things here is LoopNet remains
viewed by our customers as an essential utility to marketing their listing to end-users. CoStar is viewed as an essential utility for -- a
very valuable utility for information solutions. So as we're doing this, the marketing side of LoopNet, to me, has never looked stronger.
The information side in CoStar has never looked stronger. And there's a whole bunch of painful confusion in the middle there in
those information products, and that's going to take 1 year to sort out.
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Jeffrey from SunTrust.
Oscar D. Turner - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey, Inc., Research Division - Associate
This is Oscar Turner on for Andrew. I was wondering if you can provide more color into the line of sight to the 40% exit rate margin
target by year-end. And how should we think about the likelihood that sustained strong sales momentum leads to
higher-than-expected marketing expenses through the fourth quarter?
Scott T. Wheeler - CoStar Group, Inc. - CFO & Principal Accounting Officer
So when you look at the progression, we expect, as we commented on, that as our marketing ramps up into the second quarter,
margins seasonally go down and then they pick up into the third and then go up higher in the fourth. We've seen that same pattern
in the last couple of years and our spend is concentrated around the TV and the broadcast for the apartments marketing in the
summer months. So we really don't see that kind of pressure coming into the fourth quarter, unless something unusual happened.
Like this year, with the bankruptcy of Xceligent, we went around and spent quickly and mobilized, but at least...
